content:
2ClF(g) + O2(g) ↔ Cl2O(g) + F2O(g) &DELTA;H = 167 kJ/molrxn

During the reaction above, the product yield can be increased by increasing the temperature of the reaction. Why is this effective?

answers.A: <label>A. The reaction is endothermic; therefore adding heat will shift it to the right.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Increasing the temperature increases the speed of the molecules, meaning there will be more collisions between them.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The reactants are less massive than the products, and an increase in temperature will cause their kinetic energy to increase more than that of the products.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The increase in temperature allows for a higher percentage of molecular collisions to occur with the proper orientation to create the product.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The reaction is endothermic, meaning energy is a reactant (appears on the left side of the equation). Adding stress to the left side increases the rate of the forward reaction, creating more products.

content:
CH3NH2(aq) + H2O(l) ↔ OH-(aq) + CH3NH3+(aq)

The above equation represents the reaction between the base methylamine (Kb = 4.38 × 10-4) and water. Which of the following best represents the concentrations of the various species at equilibrium?

answers.A: <label>A. [OH<sup class="frac">-</sup>] > [CH<sub class="frac">3</sub>NH<sub class="frac">2</sub>] = [CH<sub class="frac">3</sub>NH<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">+</sup>]</label>
answers.B: <label>B. [OH<sup class="frac">-</sup>] = [CH<sub class="frac">3</sub>NH<sub class="frac">2</sub>] = [CH<sub class="frac">3</sub>NH<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">+</sup>]</label>
answers.C: <label>C. [CH<sub class="frac">3</sub>NH<sub class="frac">2</sub>] > [OH<sup class="frac">-</sup>] > [CH<sub class="frac">3</sub>NH<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">+</sup>]</label>
answers.D: <label>D. [CH<sub class="frac">3</sub>NH<sub class="frac">2</sub>] > [OH<sup class="frac">-</sup>] = [CH<sub class="frac">3</sub>NH<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">+</sup>]</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Weak bases do not ionize fully in solution, and most of the methylamine molecules will not deprotonate. The hydroxide and conjugate acid ions are created in a 1:1 ratio and therefore will be equal.

content: The following diagram shows the relative atomic sizes of three different elements from the same period. Which of the following statements must be true?

answers.A: <label>A. The effective nuclear charge would be the greatest in element X.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The first ionization energy will be greatest in element X.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The electron shielding effect will be greatest in element Z.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The electronegativity value will be greatest in element Z.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Moving across a period, atomic size decreases. Therefore, atom Z will be farthest to the right (have the most protons), and thus will have the highest electronegativity value.

content: A sealed, rigid container contains three gases: 28.0 g of nitrogen, 40.0 g of argon, and 36.0 g of water vapor. If the total pressure exerted by the gases is 2.0 atm, what is the partial pressure of the nitrogen?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C There are 1 mole of N2, 1 mole of Ar, and 2 moles of water in the container. The mole fraction of nitrogen is: 1/4 = 0.25.

PN2 = (XN2)(Ptotal)

PN2 = (0.25)(2.0) = 0.50 atm

content: A sample of liquid NH3 is brought to its boiling point. Which of the following occurs during the boiling process?

answers.A: <label>A. The N-H bonds within the NH<sub class="frac">3</sub> molecules break apart.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The overall temperature of the solution rises as the NH<sub class="frac">3</sub> molecules speed up.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The amount of energy within the system remains constant.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The hydrogen bonds holding separate NH<sub class="frac">3</sub> molecules together break apart.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D When a covalent substance undergoes a phase change, the bonds between the various molecules inside the substance break apart.

content:
Two half-cells are set up as follows:
Half-Cell A: Strip of Cu(s) in CuNO3(aq)
Half-Cell B: Strip of Zn(s) in Zn(NO3)2(aq)
When the cells are connected according to the following diagram, the following reaction occurs:

Correctly identify the anode and cathode in this reaction as well as where oxidation and reduction are taking place.

answers.A: <label>A. Cu is the anode where oxidation occurs, and Zn is the cathode where reduction occurs.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Cu is the anode where reduction occurs, and Zn is the cathode where oxidation occurs.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Zn is the anode where oxidation occurs, and Cu is the cathode where reduction occurs.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Zn is the anode where reduction occurs, and Cu is the cathode where oxidation occurs.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The oxidation state of copper changes from +1 to 0, meaning it has gained electrons and is being reduced, and reduction occurs at the cathode. Zinc's oxidation state changes from 0 to +2, meaning it has lost electrons and is being oxidized, which occurs at the anode.

content:
Two half-cells are set up as follows:
Half-Cell A: Strip of Cu(s) in CuNO3(aq)
Half-Cell B: Strip of Zn(s) in Zn(NO3)2(aq)
When the cells are connected according to the following diagram, the following reaction occurs:

How many moles of electrons must be transferred to create 127 g of copper?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B 127 g is equal to 2 moles of copper, which is what appears on the balanced equation. To change one mole of copper from +1 to 0, 1 mole of electrons is required. Twice as many moles being created means twice as many electrons are needed.

content:
Two half-cells are set up as follows:
Half-Cell A: Strip of Cu(s) in CuNO3(aq)
Half-Cell B: Strip of Zn(s) in Zn(NO3)2(aq)
When the cells are connected according to the following diagram, the following reaction occurs:

If the Cu+ + e- → Cu(s) half reaction has a standard reduction potential of +0.52 V, what is the standard reduction potential for the Zn2+ + 2e- → Zn(s) half reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Ecell = Ered + Eox

1.28 V = 0.52 V + Eox

Eox = 0.76 V

-Eox = Ered

Ered = -0.76 V

content:
Two half-cells are set up as follows:
Half-Cell A: Strip of Cu(s) in CuNO3(aq)
Half-Cell B: Strip of Zn(s) in Zn(NO3)2(aq)
When the cells are connected according to the following diagram, the following reaction occurs:

As the reaction progresses, what will happen to the overall voltage of the cell?

answers.A: <label>A. It will increase as [Zn<sup class="frac">2+</sup>] increases.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It will increase as [Cu<sup class="frac">+</sup>] increases.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It will decrease as [Zn<sup class="frac">2+</sup>] increases.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C As the reaction progresses, [Cu+] will decrease and [Zn2+] will increase. With a lower concentration on the reactants side and a higher concentration on the products side, the reaction will shift left, decreasing the overall potential of the reaction.

content:
Two half-cells are set up as follows:
Half-Cell A: Strip of Cu(s) in CuNO3(aq)
Half-Cell B: Strip of Zn(s) in Zn(NO3)2(aq)
When the cells are connected according to the following diagram, the following reaction occurs:

What will happen in the salt bridge as the reaction progresses?

answers.A: <label>A. The Na<sup class="frac">+</sup> ions will flow to the Cu/Cu<sup class="frac">+</sup> half-cell.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The Br<sup class="frac">-</sup> ions will flow to the Cu/Cu<sup class="frac">+</sup> half-cell.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Electrons will transfer from the Cu/Cu<sup class="frac">+</sup> half-cell to the Zn/Zn<sup class="frac">2+</sup> half-cell.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Electrons will transfer from the Zn/Zn<sup class="frac">2+</sup> half-cell to the Cu/Cu<sup class="frac">+</sup> half-cell.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The electron transfer does not happen across the salt bridge, eliminating options (C) and (D). As the reaction progresses and [Cu+] decreases in the copper half-cell, positively charged sodium ions are transferred in to keep the charge balanced within the half-cell.

content: For a reaction involving nitrogen monoxide inside a sealed flask, the value for the reaction quotient (Q) was found to be 1.1 × 102 at a given point. If, after this point, the amount of NO gas in the flask increased, which reaction is most likely taking place in the flask?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D When Q > Kc, the numerator of the equilibrium expression (the product concentration) is too big, and the equation shifts to the left. This is true for both (A) and (B), meaning [NO] would decrease. When Q < Kc, the numerator/product concentrations need to increase. This is the case in (C) and (D), but NO(g) is only a product in (D).

content: Which of the following substances has an asymmetrical molecular structure?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A

The only tricky bit here it to remember that boron is considered stable with only six electrons in its valence shell.

content: The diagram above shows the speed distribution of molecules in a gas held at 200 K. Which of the following representations would best represent the gas at a higher temperature? (Note: The original line is shown as a dashed line in the answer options.)
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D At a higher temperature, the average velocity of the gas molecules would be greater. Additionally, they would have a greater spread of potential velocities, which would lead to a wider curve.

content: Nitrogen's electronegativity value is between those of phosphorus and oxygen. Which of the following correctly describes the relationship between the three values?

answers.A: <label>A. The value for nitrogen is less than that of phosphorus because nitrogen is larger, but greater than that of oxygen because nitrogen has a greater effective nuclear charge.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The value for nitrogen is less than that of phosphorus because nitrogen has fewer protons but greater than that of oxygen because nitrogen has less valence electrons.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The value for nitrogen is greater than that of phosphorus because nitrogen has less electrons, but less than that of oxygen because nitrogen is smaller.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The value for nitrogen is greater than that of phosphorus because nitrogen is smaller, but less than that of oxygen because nitrogen has a smaller effective nuclear charge.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Nitrogen only has two shells of electrons while phosphorus has three, making nitrogen smaller and more able to attract additional electrons, meaning a higher electronegativity. Nitrogen and oxygen both have two shells, but oxygen has more protons and an effective nuclear charge of +6 vs. nitrogen's effective nuclear charge of +5. Thus, oxygen has a higher electronegativity.

content: A sample of a compound known to consist of only carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen is found to have a total mass of 29.05 g. If the mass of the carbon is 18.02 g and the mass of the hydrogen is 3.03 g, what is the empirical formula of the compound?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B First, the mass of the oxygen must be calculated: 29.05 g - 18.02 g - 3.03 g = 8.00 g.

Converting each of those to moles yields 0.5 moles of oxygen, 1.5 moles of carbon, and 3.0 moles of hydrogen. Thus, for every one oxygen atom there are three carbon atoms and six hydrogen atoms.

content:
A solution of carbonic acid, H2CO3, is titrated with sodium hydroxide, NaOH. The following graph is produced:

In addition to OH-, what species are present in the solution during section III of the graph?

answers.A: <label>A. H<sub class="frac">2</sub>CO<sub class="frac">3</sub>, HCO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup>, and CO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup></label>
answers.B: <label>B. H<sub class="frac">2</sub>CO<sub class="frac">3</sub> and HCO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup></label>
answers.C: <label>C. HCO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup> and CO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup></label>
answers.D: <label>D. H<sub class="frac">2</sub>CO<sub class="frac">3</sub> and CO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup></label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C During sections I and II, the following reaction occurs: H2CO3(aq) + OH-(aq) ↔ HCO3- (aq) + H2O(l). The endpoint of that is reached when all H2CO3 has reacted, meaning that in sections III and IV the following occurs: HCO3- (aq) + OH-(aq) ↔ CO32-(aq) + H2O(l).

content:
A solution of carbonic acid, H2CO3, is titrated with sodium hydroxide, NaOH. The following graph is produced:

What is the magnitude of the first dissociation constant?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B pH = pKa + [HCO3-]/[H2CO3]. At a point in the graph where half of all the acid has reacted, the last part of the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation cancels out, leaving pH = pKa. The first equivalence point occurs at a volume of 10 mL, and thus the half-equivalence point is at a volume of 5 mL. The pH at this point is 4, so: 4 = -logKa. Ka is somewhere around 10-4.

content:
A solution of carbonic acid, H2CO3, is titrated with sodium hydroxide, NaOH. The following graph is produced:

If the concentration of the sodium hydroxide is increased prior to repeating the titration, what effect, if any, would that have on the graph?

answers.A: <label>A. The graph would not change at all.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The pH values at the equivalence points would increase.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The equivalence points would be reached with less volume of NaOH added.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The slope of the equivalence points would decrease.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C A more concentrated NaOH solution means more moles of NaOH are added per drop, so a lower volume of NaOH would be needed to add enough moles to reach the equivalence point.

content:
Two solutions of potassium carbonate and sodium chloride are mixed together, and the particulate representation below shows what is present after the reaction has gone to completion.

Which of the two original solutions is the limiting reagent and why?

answers.A: <label>A. The potassium carbonate, because of the polyatomic anion</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The potassium carbonate, because there is no carbonate left after the reaction</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The calcium chloride, because there is an excess of calcium ions post-reaction</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The calcium chloride, because the component ions are smaller than those in potassium carbonate</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B If extra Ca2+ ions are in solution, that means there were not enough CO32- ions present for the Ca2+ ions to fully react.

content:
In which of the following circumstances is the value for Keq always greater than 1?

&DELTA;H &DELTA;S
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Via Keq = , if ΔG is negative the value for K will be greater than one. Via ΔG = ΔH - TΔS, ΔG is always negative when ΔH is negative and ΔS is positive.

content:
The structure of two oxoacids is shown below:

Which would be a stronger acid, and why?

answers.A: <label>A. HOCl, because the H–O bond is weaker than in HOF as chlorine is larger than fluorine</label>
answers.B: <label>B. HOCl, because the H–O bond is stronger than in HOF as chlorine has a higher electronegativity than fluorine</label>
answers.C: <label>C. HOF, because the H–O bond is stronger than in HOCl as fluorine has a higher electronegativity than chlorine</label>
answers.D: <label>D. HOF, because the H–O bond is weaker than in HOCl as fluorine is smaller than chlorine</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The weaker the O-H bond is in an oxoacid, the stronger the acid will be because the H+ ions are more likely to dissociate. The O-F bond in HOF is stronger than the O-Cl bond in HOCl because fluorine is smaller (and thus more electronegative) than chlorine. If the O-F bond is stronger, the O-H bond is correspondingly weaker, making HOF the stronger acid.

content: During a chemical reaction, NO(g) gets reduced and no nitrogen-containing compound is oxidized. Which of the following is a possible product of this reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The oxidation state of nitrogen in NO is +2. If the nitrogen is reduced, that value must get more negative. The oxidation state of nitrogen in N2 is 0, so that fits the bill. The oxidation state on the nitrogen in the other choices is greater than +2.

content: Which of the following pairs of substances would make a good buffer solution?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A A buffer is made up of either a weak acid and its salt or a weak base and its salt. Option (B) has a strong acid and strong base, option (C) has a strong acid and its salt, and option (D) has a weak acid and a weak base.

content:
Inside a calorimeter, 100.0 mL of 1.0 M hydrocyanic acid (HCN), a weak acid, and 100.0 mL of 0.50 M sodium hydroxide are mixed. The temperature of the mixture rises from 21.5 °C to 28.5 °C. The specific heat of the mixture is approximately 4.2 J/g°C, and the density is identical to that of water.

Identify the correct net ionic equation for the reaction that takes place.
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A HCN will lose its proton to the hydroxide, creating a conjugate base and water.

content:
Inside a calorimeter, 100.0 mL of 1.0 M hydrocyanic acid (HCN), a weak acid, and 100.0 mL of 0.50 M sodium hydroxide are mixed. The temperature of the mixture rises from 21.5 °C to 28.5 °C. The specific heat of the mixture is approximately 4.2 J/g°C, and the density is identical to that of water.

What is the approximate amount of heat released during the reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The mass of the mixture is 200.0 g; this is from the volume being 200.0 mL and the density of the mixture being 1.0 g/mL. ΔT is 7.0 °C and c is 4.2 J/g°C.

q = mcΔT

q = (200.0 g)(4.2 J/g°C)(7.0 °C) = 5880 J ≈ 5.9kJ

content:
Inside a calorimeter, 100.0 mL of 1.0 M hydrocyanic acid (HCN), a weak acid, and 100.0 mL of 0.50 M sodium hydroxide are mixed. The temperature of the mixture rises from 21.5 °C to 28.5 °C. The specific heat of the mixture is approximately 4.2 J/g°C, and the density is identical to that of water.

As ΔT increases, what happens to the equilibrium constant and why?

answers.A: <label>A. The equilibrium constant increases because more products are created.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The equilibrium constant increases because the rate of the forward reaction increases.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The equilibrium constant decreases because the equilibrium shifts to the left.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The value for the equilibrium constant is unaffected by temperature and will not change.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C This is an exothermic reaction; therefore heat is generated as a product. An increase in temperature thus causes a shift to the left, decreasing the numerator and increasing the denominator in the equilibrium expression. This decreases the overall value of K.

content:
Inside a calorimeter, 100.0 mL of 1.0 M hydrocyanic acid (HCN), a weak acid, and 100.0 mL of 0.50 M sodium hydroxide are mixed. The temperature of the mixture rises from 21.5 °C to 28.5 °C. The specific heat of the mixture is approximately 4.2 J/g°C, and the density is identical to that of water.

If the experiment is repeated with 200.0 mL of 1.0 M HCN and 100. mL of 0.50 M NaOH, what would happen to the values for ΔT and ΔHrxn?

ΔT ΔHrxn

answers.B: <label>B. Stay the same     Stay the same</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The NaOH is limiting (0.050 mol vs. 0.100 mol in the original reaction), and adding even more excess HCN will not change the amount of HCN that acutally reacts with OH-. So, the value for ΔHrxn stays the same. However, the overall mixture will have a greater mass (300.0 g), which means the temperature change will not be as large.

content: The following diagrams show the Lewis structures of four different molecules. Which molecule would travel the farthest in a paper chromatography experiment using a polar solvent?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A In a polar solvent, polar molecules will be the most soluble (like dissolves like). Of the four options, methanol and acetone would both have dipoles, but those of methanol would be significantly stronger due to the H-bonding.

content: The first ionization energy for a neutral atom of chlorine is 1.25 MJ/mol and the first ionization energy for a neutral atom of argon is 1.52 MJ/mol. How would the first ionization energy value for a neutral atom of potassum compare to those values?

answers.A: <label>A. It would be greater than both because potassium carries a greater nuclear charge then either chlorine or argon.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It would be greater than both because the size of a potassium atom is smaller than an atom of either chlorine or argon.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It would be less than both because there are more electrons in potassium, meaning they repel each other more effectively and less energy is needed to remove one.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It would be less than both because a valence electron of potassium is farther from the nucleus than one of either chlorine or argon.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Potassium's first valence electron is in the fourth energy level, but both chlorine and argon's first valence electron is in the third energy level.

content: Which net ionic equation below represents a possible reaction that takes place when a strip of magnesium metal is oxidized by a solution of chromium (III) nitrate?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Cr3+ needs to gain three electrons to reduce into Cr(s), while Mg(s) loses 2 electrons to oxidize into Mg2+. To balance the electrons, the reduction half-reaction must be multiplied by two and the oxidation half-reaction must be multiplied by three in order to have six electrons on each side. The nitrate ion is a spectator and would not appear in the net ionic equation.

content:
PCl3(g) + Cl2(g) ↔ PCl5(g) ΔH = -92.5 kJ/mol

In which of the following ways could the reaction above be manipulated to create more product?

answers.A: <label>A. Decreasing the concentration of PCl<sub class="frac">3</sub></label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Increasing the pressure in an equilibrium reaction with any gas molecules causes a shift to the side with less gas molecules-in this case, the product.

content: A pure solid substance is heated strongly. It first melts into a liquid, then boils and becomes a gas. Which of the following heating curves correctly shows the relationship between temperature and heat added?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A During a phase change, all of the energy added goes towards breaking the intermolecular forces holding the molecules together. During this time, the speed of the molecules (and thus the temperature) does not rise.

content:
Consider the following reaction showing photosynthesis:

6CO2(g) + 6H2O(l) → C6H12O6(s) + 6O2(g) DH = + 2800 kJ/mol

Which of the following is true regarding the thermal energy in this system?

answers.A: <label>A. It is transferred from the surroundings to the reaction.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It is transferred from the reaction to the surroundings.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It is transferred from the reactants to the products.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It is transferred from the products to the reactants.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A In an endothermic reaction, heat is transferred into the reaction system.

content:
SO2Cl2 → SO2(g) + Cl2(g)

At 600 K, SO2Cl2 will decompose to form sulfur dioxide and chlorine gas via the above equation. If the reaction is found to be first order overall, which of the following will cause an increase in the half life of SO2Cl2?

answers.A: <label>A. Increasing the initial concentration of SO<sub class="frac">2</sub>Cl<sub class="frac">2</sub></label>
answers.B: <label>B. Increasing the temperature at which the reaction occurs</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Decreasing the overall pressure in the container</label>
answers.D: <label>D. None of these will increase the half life</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D None of the options would decrease the rate of reaction, which would be required for the half-life of the reactant to increase.

content:
2SO2(g) + O2(g) → 2SO3(g)
4.0 mol of gaseous SO2 and 6.0 mol of O2 gas are allowed to react in a sealed container.

Which particulate drawing best represents the contents of the flask after the reaction goes to completion?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C To determine the number of moles of SO3 created, stoichiometry must be used.

SO2: 4 mol SO2 × = 4 mol SO3

O2 = 6 mol O2 × = 12 mol SO3

The oxygen is in excess, and only 2.0 mol of it will react. (As every 2 moles SO2 react with 1 mol of O2). Thus, 4 mol of SO3 are created and 4.0 mol of O2 remain.

content:
2SO2(g) + O2(g) â†’ 2SO3(g)
4.0 mol of gaseous SO2 and 6.0 mol of O2 gas are allowed to react in a sealed container.

What percentage of the original pressure will the final pressure in the container be equal to?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B If 4 mol of SO3 are created and 4.0 mol of O2 remain, there are 8.0 mol of gas present after the reaction. Prior to the reaction there were 10.0 mol of gas. If there are 8/10 = 80% as many moles after the reaction, there is also 80% as much pressure.

content:
2SO2(g) + O2(g) â†’ 2SO3(g)
4.0 mol of gaseous SO2 and 6.0 mol of O2 gas are allowed to react in a sealed container.

At a given point in the reaction, all three gases are present at the same temperature. Which gas molecules will have the highest velocity and why?

answers.A: <label>A. The O<sub class="frac">2</sub> molecules, because they have the least mass</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The O<sub class="frac">2</sub> molecules, because they are the smallest</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The SO<sub class="frac">3</sub> molecules, because they are products in the reaction</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Molecules of all three gases will have the same speed because they have the same temperature.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A If all gases are at the same temperature, they have the same amount of kinetic energy. Given that KE = 1/2 mv2, if all three gases have the same KE, the gas with the least mass must have the highest velocity in order to compensate.

content:
2SO2(g) + O2(g) â†’ 2SO3(g)
4.0 mol of gaseous SO2 and 6.0 mol of O2 gas are allowed to react in a sealed container.

Under which of the following conditions would the gases in the container most deviate from ideal conditions and why?

answers.A: <label>A. Low pressures because the gas molecules would be spread far apart</label>
answers.B: <label>B. High pressures because the gas molecules will be colliding frequently</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Low temperatures, because the intermolecular forces between the gas molecules would increase</label>
answers.D: <label>D. High temperatures, because the gas molecules are moving too fast to interact with each other</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C One of the assumptions of kinetic molecular theory is that the amount of intermolecular forces between the gas molecules is negligible. If the molecules are moving very slowly, the IMFs between them are more likely to cause deviations from ideal behavior.

content: Four different acids are added to beakers of water, and the following diagrams represent the species present in each solution at equilibrium. Which acid has the highest pH?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The strength of an acid is dependent on the amount it dissociates in solution. A low dissociation is signified by a low presence of hydrogen ions. The weakest acid is choice (C).

content: Which expression below should be used to calculate the mass of copper that can be plated out of a 1.0 M Cu(NO3)2 solution using a current of 0.75 A for 5.0 minutes?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A

content: Lewis diagrams for the nitrate and nitrite ions are shown below. Choose the statement that correctly describes the relationship between the two ions in terms of bond length and bond energy.

answers.A: <label>A. Nitrite has longer and stronger bonds than nitrate.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Nitrite has longer and weaker bonds than nitrate.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Nitrite has shorter and stronger bonds than nitrate.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Nitrite has shorter and weaker bonds than nitrate.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Nitrate has a bond order of = 1.33. Nitite has a bond order of = 1.5. A higher bond order means shorter and stronger bonds.

content: Examining data obtained from mass spectrometry supports which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. The common oxidation states of elements</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Atomic size trends within the periodic table</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Ionization energy trends within the periodic table</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Mass spectrometry is used to determine the masses for individual atoms of an element. Through mass spectrometry, it is proven that each element has more than one possible mass.

content: A 2.0 L flask holds 0.40 g of helium gas. If the helium is evacuated into a larger container while the temperature is held constant, what will the effect on the entropy of the helium be?

answers.A: <label>A. It will remain constant as the number of helium molecules does not change.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It will decrease as the gas will be more ordered in the larger flask.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It will decrease because the molecules will collide with the sides of the larger flask less often than they did in the smaller flask.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It will increase as the gas molecules will be more dispersed in the larger flask.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Entropy is a measure of a system's disorder. In a larger flask, the gas molecules will spread farther apart and become more disordered.

content:
NO2 gas is placed in a sealed, evacuated container and allowed to decompose via the following equation:
2NO2(g) ↔ 2NO(g) + O2(g)
The graph below indicates the change in concentration for each species over time.

Using the numbers of the lines on the graph, identify which line belongs to which species.
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The only species that is present at t = 0 is the NO2, allowing us to identify line III. When identifying line I vs. line II, the NO will be generated twice as quickly as the O2 due to the coefficients, meaning [NO] will increase about twice as quickly as [O2].

content:
NO2 gas is placed in a sealed, evacuated container and allowed to decompose via the following equation:
2NO2(g) ↔ 2NO(g) + O2(g)
The graph below indicates the change in concentration for each species over time.

What is happening to the rate of the forward reaction at t = 60 s?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C At equilibrium, the concentrations of all species in the reaction are remaining constant, which shows up as a flat line on the graph. The rate of both the forward and reverse reactions are constant at equilibrium.

content:
NO2 gas is placed in a sealed, evacuated container and allowed to decompose via the following equation:
2NO2(g) ↔ 2NO(g) + O2(g)
The graph below indicates the change in concentration for each species over time.

As the reaction progresses, what happens to the value of the equilibrium constant Kp if the temperature remains constant?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The only factor that can affect the value of the equilibrium constant is temperature. If the temperature does not change, neither does the equilibrium constant.

content:
NO2 gas is placed in a sealed, evacuated container and allowed to decompose via the following equation:
2NO2(g) ↔ 2NO(g) + O2(g)
The graph below indicates the change in concentration for each species over time.

What would happen to the slope of the NO2 line if additional O2 were injected into the container?

answers.A: <label>A. It would increase, then level off.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It would decrease, then level off.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A If additional O2 were injected into the container, the reaction would shift left, increasing the amount of NO2 present. Eventually, the reaction would reach equilibrium again, meaning the lines would level out.

content:
NO2 gas is placed in a sealed, evacuated container and allowed to decompose via the following equation:
2NO2(g) ↔ 2NO(g) + O2(g)
The graph below indicates the change in concentration for each species over time.

Using the graph, how could you determine the instantaneous rate of disappearance of NO2 at t = 30 s?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B To determine the change in concentration at a specific time, we would need the slope of the line at that point. As the line is curved, the only way to do that (without calculus) is to draw a line tangent to the curve at that point and measure its slope.

content:
A proposed mechanism for a reaction is as follows:

NO2 + F2 →NO2F + F Slow step

F + NO2 → NO2F Fast step

What is the order of the overall reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The overall rate law is always equal to the rate law for slowest elementary step, which can be determined using the coefficients of the reactants. In this case, rate = k[NO2][F2]. To get the overall order, we add the exponents in the rate law. 1 + 1 = 2

content: Starting with a stock solution of 18.0 M H2SO4, what is the proper procedure to create a 1.00 L sample of a 3.0 M solution of H2SO4 in a volumetric flask?

answers.A: <label>A. Add 167 mL of the stock solution to the flask, then fill the flask the rest of the way with distilled water while swirling the solution.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Add 600 mL of the stock solution to the flask, then fill the flask the rest of the way with distilled water while swirling the solution.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Fill the flask partway with water, then add 167 mL of the stock solution, swirling to mix it. Last, fill the flask the rest of the way with distilled water.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Fill the flask partway with water, then add 600 mL of the stock solution, swirling to mix it. Last, fill the flask the rest of the way with distilled water.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Use M1V1 = M2V2 to determine the necessary volume of stock solution.

(18.0 M)V1 = (3.0 M)(1.0 L)

V1 = 0.167 L = 167 mL

When creating solutions with acid, you always add some water first, as the process is extremely exothermic and the water will absorb the generated heat.

content: The reaction shown in the following diagram is accompanied by a large increase in temperature. If all molecules shown are in their gaseous state, which statement accurately describes the reaction?

answers.A: <label>A. It is an exothermic reaction in which entropy increases.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It is an exothermic reaction in which entropy decreases.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It is an endothermic reaction in which entropy increases.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It is an endothermic reaction in which entropy decreases.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The temperature increase is indicative of energy being released, meaning the reaction is exothermic. The entropy (disorder) of the system is increasing as it moves from three gas molecules to five.

content: A student mixes equimolar amounts of KOH and Cu(NO3)2 in a beaker. Which of the following particulate diagrams correctly shows all species present after the reaction occurs?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The overall reaction (excluding spectator ions) is: 2 OH- + Cu2+ â†’ Cu(OH)2(s). Both the K+ and the NO3- are spectator ions which are present in solution both before and after the reaction. Additionally, if equimolar amounts of the two reactants are initially present, the OH- will run out before the Cu2+, meaning that some Cu2+ ions will also be present in the final solution.

content: Based on the strength of the intermolecular forces in each substance, estimate from greatest to smallest the vapor pressures of each substance in liquid state at the same temperature.
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Vapor pressure is dependent on intermolecular forces. The weaker the IMFs are, the easier it is for molecules to escape from the surface of the liquid. To begin, polar molecules have stronger IMFs than nonpolar molecules. Methanol and ethanal are both polar, but methanol has hydrogen bonding meaning it has stronger IMFs (and thus a lower vapor pressure) than ethanal. Ethene and propane are both nonpolar, but propane is larger meaning it is more polarizable than ethene and thus has stronger IMFs and lower vapor pressure.

content: When in liquid state, which two substances are most likely to be miscible with water?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Water is polar, and using "like dissolves like," we know that only polar solvents will be able to fully mix with it to create a homogenous solution.

content: Between propane and ethene, which will likely have the higher boiling point and why?

answers.A: <label>A. propane, because it has a greater molar mass</label>
answers.B: <label>B. propane, because it has a more polarizable electron cloud</label>
answers.C: <label>C. ethene, because of the double bond</label>
answers.D: <label>D. ethene, because it is smaller in size</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Both are nonpolar, but propane has a lot more electrons and thus is more polarizable than ethene.

content:
4NH3(g) + 5O2(g) → 4NO(g) + 6H2O(g)

The above reaction will experience a rate increase by the addition of a cataylst such as platinum. Which of the following best explains why?

answers.A: <label>A. The catalyst increases the overall frequency of collisions in the reactant molecules.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The catalyst increases the frequency of collisions that occur at the proper orientation in the reactant molecules.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The catalyst introduces a new reaction mechanism for the reaction.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The catalyst increases the activation energy for the reaction.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Catalysts work by creating a new reaction pathway with a lower activation energy than the original pathway.

content: The graph below shows the amount of potential energy between two hydrogen atoms as the distance between them changes. At which point in the graph would a molecule of H2 be the most stable?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The molecule would be the most stable when it has the largest attractive potential energy, which is represented by a negative sign. While the magnitude of the potential energy may be larger at (A), it is repulsive at that point because the nuclei are too close together.

content:
N2(g) + O2(g) + Cl2(g) ↔ 2NOCl(g) ΔG째 = 132.6 kJ/mol

For the equilibrium above, what would happen to the value of ΔG째 if the concentration of N2 were to increase and why?

answers.A: <label>A. It would increase as the reaction would become more thermodynamically favored.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It would increase as the reaction would shift right and create more products.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It would decrease because there are more reactants present.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Adding (or removing) any species in an equilibrium reaction does not change the equilibrium constant and also does not change the magnitude of the Gibbs free energy at standard conditions.

content:
C(s) + 2S(s) → CS2(l) &DELTA;H = +92.0 kJ/mol

Which of the following energy level diagrams gives an accurate representation of the above reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C A positive H means the reaction is endothermic, so the products have more bond energy than the reactants. The difference between the energy levels of the products and reactants is equal to ΔH. (The difference between the energy level of the reactants and the top of the hump is the value for the activation energy.)

content: Two alloys are shown in the diagrams below—bronze, and steel. Which of the following correctly describes the malleability of both alloys compared to their primary metals?

answers.A: <label>A. Bronze's malleability would be comparable to that of copper, but steel's malleability would be significantly lower than that of iron.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Bronze's malleability would be significantly higher than that of copper, but steel's malleability would be comparable to that of iron.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Both bronze and steel would have malleability values similar to those of their primary metals.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Both bronze and steel would have malleability values greater than those of their primary metals.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Alloys of any type generally have malleability that is very similar to the metals from which they are created.

content: A compound is made up of entirely silicon and oxygen atoms. If there are 14.00 g of silicon and 32.0 g of oxygen present, what is the empirical formula of the compound?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B 14.0 g of Si is 0.50 mol, and 32.0 g of oxygen is 2.0 mol. Converting that to a whole number ratio gives us 1 mol of Si for every 4 moles of O.

content: The volume of a gas is charted over time, giving the above results. Which of the following options provides a possibel explinatin of what was happening to the gas during each phase of the graph?

answers.A: <label>A. During phase I, the temperature decreased while the pressure increased. During phase II, the temperature was held constant as the pressure decreased.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. During phase I, the temperature increased while the pressure was held constant. During phase II, the temperature and pressure both decreased.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. During phase I, the temperature was held constant while the pressure increased. During phase II, the temperature and pressure both decreased.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. During phase I, the temperature and pressure both increased. During phase II, the temperature was held constant while the pressure decreased.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B In phase I, an increased temperature means the molecules are moving faster and will spread out more, leading to an increased volume. For the volume to remain constant in phase II, either both pressure and volume have to remain constant, or they both have to increase or decrease together, as they are inversely proportional.

content: A solution of sulfurous acid, H2SO3, is present in an aqueous solution. Which of the following represents the concentrations of three different ions in solution?

answers.A: <label>A. [SO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup>] > [HSO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup>] > [H<sub class="frac">2</sub>SO<sub class="frac">3</sub>]</label>
answers.B: <label>B. [H<sub class="frac">2</sub>SO<sub class="frac">3</sub>] > [HSO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup>] > [SO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2</sup><sup class="frac">-</sup>]</label>
answers.C: <label>C. [H<sub class="frac">2</sub>SO<sub class="frac">3</sub>] > [HSO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup>] = [SO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2</sup><sup class="frac">-</sup>]</label>
answers.D: <label>D. [SO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2</sup><sup class="frac">-</sup>] = [HSO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup>] > [H<sub class="frac">2</sub>SO<sub class="frac">3</sub>]</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Weak acids have a very low dissociation value, and for polyprotic weak acids the second dissociation is always weaker than the first.

content:
2NO(g) + Br2(g) ↔ 2NOBr(g)

The above experiment was performed several times, and the following data was gathered:

What is the rate law for this reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Between trial 1 and 3, the concentration of NO doubled while the concentration of Br2 held constant, and the rate went up by a factor of four. So, the reaction is second order with respect to NO. Between trial 1 and 2, the concentration of NO was held constant while the concentration of Br2 doubled, and the rate went up by a factor of two. Thus, the reaction is first order with respect to Br2.

content:
SF4(g) + H2O(1) → SO2(g) + 4HF(g) ΔH = -828 kJ/mol

Which of the following statements accurately describes the above reaction?

answers.A: <label>A. The entropy of the reactants exceeds that of the products.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. This reaction is never thermodynamically favored.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The bond strength of the reactants exceeds that of the products.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D One way to calculate enthalpy is by subtracting the strength of the bonds broken in the reactants from the strength of the bonds formed in the products. If the first value is greater than the second value, the overall enthalpy change will be negative.

content:
20.0 mL of 1.0 M Na2CO3 is placed in a beaker and titrated with a solution of 1.0 M Ca(NO3)2, resulting in the creation of a precipitate. The conductivity of the solution is measured as the titration progresses.

How much Ca(NO3)2 must be added to reach the equivalence point?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Equivalence is reached when the conductivity of the solution reaches it's minimum value, meaning as many of the precipitate ions are out of solution as possible. As the formula of the precipitate is CaCO3, for every mole of sodium carbonate in the beaker, one mole of calcium nitrate will be needed. As both solutions have equal molarity, equal volumes of each would be necessary to ensure the moles are equal.

content:
20.0 mL of 1.0 M Na2CO3 is placed in a beaker and titrated with a solution of 1.0 M Ca(NO3)2, resulting in the creation of a precipitate. The conductivity of the solution is measured as the titration progresses.

Which of the following diagrams correctly shows the species present in the solution in significant amounts at the equivalence point?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A At the equivalence point, the moles of Ca2+ and CO32- in solution will be negligible.

content:
20.0 mL of 1.0 M Na2CO3 is placed in a beaker and titrated with a solution of 1.0 M Ca(NO3)2, resulting in the creation of a precipitate. The conductivity of the solution is measured as the titration progresses.

What will happen to the conductivity of the solution after additional Ca(NO3)2 is added past the equivalence point?

answers.A: <label>A. The conductivity will increase as additional ions are being added to the solution.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The conductivity will stay constant as the precipitation reaction has gone to completion.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The conductivity will decrease as the solution will be diluted with the addition of additional Ca(NO<sub class="frac">3</sub>)<sub class="frac">2</sub>.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The conductivity will stay constant as equilibrium has been established.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The Ca2+ ions will have nothing to react with, so they will just remain in solution (as will the extra NO3- ions being added), increasing the conductivity.

content:
20.0 mL of 1.0 M Na2CO3 is placed in a beaker and titrated with a solution of 1.0 M Ca(NO3)2, resulting in the creation of a precipitate. The conductivity of the solution is measured as the titration progresses.

If the experiment were repeated and the Na2CO3 was diluted to 40.0 mL with distilled water prior to the titration, how would that affect the volume of Ca(NO3)2 needed to reach the equivalence point?

answers.A: <label>A. It would be cut in half.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It would decrease by a factor of 1.5.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The equivalence point is reached when there are equal moles of each reactant present. Diluting the sodium carbonate solution will not change the number of moles of Na2CO3 present in solution.

content:
2CO(g) + O2(g) → 2CO2(g)

2.0 mol of CO(g) and 2.0 mol of O2(g) are pumped into a rigid, evacuated 4.0-L container, where they react to form CO2(g). Which of the following values does NOT represent a potential set of concentrations for each gas at a given point during the reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C For every two moles of CO that react, one mole of O2 will also react. If one mole of CO reacts, half a mole of O2 will react. At that point, the concentration of CO will be (1.0 mol/4.0 L = 0.25 M) and the concentration of the O2 will be (1.5 mol/4.0 L = 0.38 M), rendering choice (C) impossible.

content: Neutral atoms of chlorine are bombarded by high-energy photons, causing the ejection of electrons from the various filled subshells. Electrons originally from which subshell would have the highest velocity after being ejected?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The farther away an electron is from the nucleus, the less ionization energy that is required to eject it, and as a result, the electron will have more kinetic energy after it is ejected. The 3p subshell is the farthest one that a neutral chlorine atom would have electrons in. Beware of choice (D); chlorine does not have a 3d subshell.

content: A sample of oxygen gas at 50 째C is heated, reaching a final temperature of 100 째C. Which statement best describes the behavior of the gas molecules?

answers.A: <label>A. Their velocity increases by a factor of two.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Their velocity increases by a factor of four.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Their kinetic energy increases by a factor of 2.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Their kinetic energy increases by a factor of less than 2.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Temperature in Kelvins is a measure of kinetic energy. When that temperature doubles, so does the kinetic energy. However, a doubling of the temperature in Celsius, while increasing the amount of kinetic energy, would not double it.

content: The average mass, in grams, of one mole of carbon atoms is equal to

answers.A: <label>A. the average mass of a single carbon atom, measured in amus.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the ratio of the number of carbon atoms to the mass of a single carbon atom.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the number of carbon atoms in one amu of carbon.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the mass, in grams, of the most abundant isotope of carbon.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A This is a straightforward concept to understand. The average atomic mass of an element on the periodic table measures both the average mass of a mole of atoms of that element in grams, as well as being the average mass of a single atom of that element in amus.

content: The diagram above best represents which type of reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A A proton is transferred from the water to the HS- ion, making the reaction an acid/base reaction.

content: Which of the following is true for all bases?

answers.A: <label>A. All bases donate OH<sup class="frac">-</sup> ions into solution.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Only strong bases create solutions in which OH<sup class="frac">-</sup> ions are present.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Only strong bases are good conductors when dissolved in solution.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. For weak bases, the concentration of the OH<sup class="frac">-</sup>ions exceeds the concentration of the base in the solution.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Strong bases dissociate to donate hydroxide ions into a solution and weak bases cause the creation of hydroxide ions by taking protons from water. However, weak bases do not protonate strongly, meaning there will not be nearly as many ions in solution for a weak base as there are for a strong base. Thus, weak bases are not good conductors.

content:
14H+(aq) + Cr2O72-(aq) + 3Ni(s) â†’
2Cr3+(aq) + 3Ni2+(aq) + 7H2O(l)
In the above reaction, a piece of solid nickel is added to a solution of potassium dichromate.

Which species is being oxidized and which is being reduced?

Oxidized    Reduced
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The Cr2O72-(aq) gains electrons to change the oxidation state on Cr from +6 to +3. The Ni(s) loses electrons to change the oxidation state on Ni from 0 to +2.

content:
14H+(aq) + Cr2O72-(aq) + 3Ni(s) â†’
2Cr3+(aq) + 3Ni2+(aq) + 7H2O(l)
In the above reaction, a piece of solid nickel is added to a solution of potassium dichromate.

How many moles of electrons are transferred when 1 mole of potassium dichromate is mixed with 3 mol of nickel?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D In one mole of dichromate, two moles of chromium are reduced, each requiring three moles of electrons. Three moles of nickel are being oxidized, each requiring two moles of electrons. Thus, six moles of electrons are being transferred.

content:
14H+(aq) + Cr2O72-(aq) + 3Ni(s) â†’
2Cr3+(aq) + 3Ni2+(aq) + 7H2O(l)
In the above reaction, a piece of solid nickel is added to a solution of potassium dichromate.

How does the pH of the solution change as the reaction progresses?

answers.A: <label>A. It increases until the solution becomes basic.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It increases, but the solution remains acidic.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It decreases until the solution becomes basic.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It decreases, but the solution remains acidic.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B As the reaction progresses, the H+ions are converting to H2O molecules. This would raise the pH of the solution. As the reaction progresses, the solution will become less acidic, but there is no mechanism for it to become basic.

content: A sample of an unknown chloride compound was dissolved in water, and then titrated with excess Pb(NO3)2 to create a precipitate. After drying, it is determined there are 0.0050 mol of precipitate present. What mass of chloride is present in the original sample?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The precipitate is PbCl2, and in every mole of precipitate there are two moles of chlorine ions. Thus, there are 0.010 mol of chlorine present in the precipitate, and through conservation of mass, the same number of moles of chlorine were present in the original sample. 0.010 mol Ã— 35.5 g = 0.355 g

content: A photoelectron spectra for which of the following atoms would show peaks at exactly three different binding energies?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Diagram B represents an atom of neon, which has three subshells: 1s, 2s, and 2p. Electrons from each subshell would have a different binding energy, yielding three peaks on a PES.

content: The bond length between any two nonmetal atoms is achieved under which of the following conditions?

answers.A: <label>A. Where the energy of interaction between the atoms is at its minimum value</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Where the nuclei of each atom exhibits the strongest attraction to the electrons of the other atom</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The point at which the attractive and repulsive forces between the two atoms are equal</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The closest point at which a valence electron from one atom can transfer to the other atom</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The bond length always corresponds to the point where the potential bond energy (a balance of the attraction and repulsion forces between the two atoms) is at its minimum value.

content: Hydrogen fluoride, HF, is a liquid at 15°C. All other hydrogen halides (represented by HX, where X is any other halogen) are gases at the same temperature. Why?

answers.A: <label>A. Fluorine has a very high electronegativity; therefore the H-F bond is stronger than any other H-X bond.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. HF is smaller than any other H-X molecule; therefore it exhibits stronger London dispersion forces.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The dipoles in a HF molecule exhibit a particularly strong attraction force to the dipoles in other HF molecules.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The H-F bond is the most ionic in character compared to all other hydrogen halides.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The bonds between HF molecules are hydrogen bonds, which are very strong dipoles created due to the high electronegativity value of fluorine. No other hydrogen halide exhibits hydrogen bonding, and thus they would have weaker intermolecular forces (and lower boiling points) than HF.

content: Two different acids with identical pH are placed in separate beakers. Identical portions of NaOH are added to each beaker, and the resulting pH is indicated in the table above. What can be determined about the strength of each acid?

answers.A: <label>A. Acid 1 is a strong acid and acid 2 is a weak acid because acid 1 resists change in pH more effectively.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Acid 1 is a strong acid and acid 2 is a weak acid because the NaOH is more effective at neutralizing acid 2.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Acid 1 is a weak acid and acid 2 is a strong acid because the concentration of the weak acid must be significantly greater to have the same pH as the strong acid.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Acid 1 is a weak acid and acid 2 is a strong acid because the concentration of the hydrogen ions will be greater in acid 2 after the NaOH addition.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Weak acids resist changes in pH more effectively than strong acids because so many molecules of weak acid are undissociated in solution. The base must cause those molecules to dissociate before affecting the pH significantly.

content: A stock solution of 12.0 M sulfuric acid is made available. What is the best procedure to make up 100. mL of 4.0 M sulfuric acid using the stock solution and water prior to mixing?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Using M1V1 = M2V2, we can calculate the amount of stock solution needed. (12.0)V1 = (4.0)(100.0), so V1 = 33.3 mL. When making solutions, always add acid to water (in order to more effectively absorb the heat of the exothermic reaction).

content:
The enthalpy values for several reactions are as follows:
(I)   CH4(g) + H2(g) → C(s) + H2O(g) &DELTA;H = -131 kJ/molrxn
(II)   CH4(g) + H2O(g) → 3H2(g) + CO(g) &DELTA;H = 206 kJ/molrxn
(III)   CO(g) + H2O(g) → CO2(g) + H2(g)
&DELTA;H = - 41 kJ/molrxn
(IV)   CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + H2O(l) &DELTA;H = -890 kJ/molrxn

In which of the reactions does the amount of energy released by the formation of bonds in the products exceed the amount of energy necessary to break the bonds of the reactants by the greatest amount?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D When calculating enthalpy, the total energy change in the reaction is always calculated by the following:

Bonds broken (reactants) - Bonds formed (products)

The more negative this value is, the more energy that was released in the bond formation of the products compared to the amount of energy necessary to break the bonds in the reactants.

content:
The enthalpy values for several reactions are as follows:
(I)   CH4(g) + H2(g) → C(s) + H2O(g) &DELTA;H = -131 kJ/molrxn
(II)   CH4(g) + H2O(g) → 3H2(g) + CO(g) &DELTA;H = 206 kJ/molrxn
(III)   CO(g) + H2O(g) → CO2(g) + H2(g)
&DELTA;H = - 41 kJ/molrxn
(IV)   CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + H2O(l) &DELTA;H = -890 kJ/molrxn

In which of the reactions is the value for &DELTA;S the most positive?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The largest entropy changes arise from phase changes. Converting a solid into a gas greatly increases the disorder in the system, and thus the entropy.

content:
The enthalpy values for several reactions are as follows:
(I)   CH4(g) + H2(g) → C(s) + H2O(g) &DELTA;H = -131 kJ/molrxn
(II)   CH4(g) + H2O(g) → 3H2(g) + CO(g) &DELTA;H = 206 kJ/molrxn
(III)   CO(g) + H2O(g) → CO2(g) + H2(g)
&DELTA;H = - 41 kJ/molrxn
(IV)   CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + H2O(l) &DELTA;H = -890 kJ/molrxn

Regarding reaction I, how would the addition of a catalyst affect the enthalpy and entropy changes for this reaction?

Enthalpy Entropy
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The addition of a catalyst speeds up the reaction but will not affect the enthalpy or the entropy values.

content:
The enthalpy values for several reactions are as follows:
(I)   CH4(g) + H2(g) → C(s) + H2O(g) &DELTA;H = -131 kJ/molrxn
(II)   CH4(g) + H2O(g) → 3H2(g) + CO(g) &DELTA;H = 206 kJ/molrxn
(III)   CO(g) + H2O(g) → CO2(g) + H2(g)
&DELTA;H = - 41 kJ/molrxn
(IV)   CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + H2O(l) &DELTA;H = -890 kJ/molrxn

Regarding reaction II, to achieve the products present in the above diagram how many moles of each reactant must be present prior to the reaction?

answers.A: <label>A. 1.0 mol of CH<sub class="frac">4</sub> and 2.0 mol of H<sub class="frac">2</sub>O</label>
answers.B: <label>B. 2.0 mol of CH<sub class="frac">4</sub> and 2.0 mol of H<sub class="frac">2</sub>O</label>
answers.C: <label>C. 2.0 mol of CH<sub class="frac">4</sub> and 3.0 mol of H<sub class="frac">2</sub>O</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 3.0 mol of CH<sub class="frac">4</sub> and 2.0 mol of H<sub class="frac">2</sub>O</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C 2.0 moles of CH4 would react with 2.0 moles of H2O, leaving 1.0 mole left. It would also create 6.0 moles of H2 and 2.0 moles of CO.

content:
The enthalpy values for several reactions are as follows:
(I)   CH4(g) + H2(g) → C(s) + H2O(g) &DELTA;H = -131 kJ/molrxn
(II)   CH4(g) + H2O(g) → 3H2(g) + CO(g) &DELTA;H = 206 kJ/molrxn
(III)   CO(g) + H2O(g) → CO2(g) + H2(g)
&DELTA;H = - 41 kJ/molrxn
(IV)   CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + H2O(l) &DELTA;H = -890 kJ/molrxn

Regarding reaction IV, how much heat is absorbed or released when 2.0 mol of CH4(g) reacts with 2.0 mol of O2(g) ?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Going from fewer gas molecules to more over the course of the reaction increases the overall disorder in the system, and thus the entropy of the reaction.

content: London dispersion forces are caused by

answers.A: <label>A. temporary dipoles created by the position of electrons around the nuclei in a molecule</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the three-dimensional intermolecular bonding present in all covalent substances</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the uneven electron-to-proton ratio found on individual atoms of a molecule</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the electronegativity differences between the different atoms in a molecule</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A London dispersion forces are created by temporary dipoles due to the constant motion of electrons in an atom or molecule.

content: What is the general relationship between temperature and entropy for diatomic gases?

answers.A: <label>A. They are completely independent of each other; temperature has no effect on entropy.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There is a direct relationship, because at higher temperatures there is an increase in energy dispersal.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There is an inverse relationship, because at higher temperatures substances are more likely to be in a gaseous state.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It depends on the specific gas and the strength of the intermolecular forces between individual molecules.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The higher the temperature of any substance, the larger the range of velocities the molecules of that substance can have, and thus the more disorder the substance can have. A Maxwell-Boltzmann diagram represents this in a graphical form.

content:
Which of the following pairs of ions would make the best buffer with a basic pH?

Ka for HC3H2O2 = 1.75 × 10-5

Ka for HPO42- = 4.8 × 10-13

answers.A: <label>A. H<sub class="frac">2</sub>SO<sub class="frac">4</sub> and H<sub class="frac">2</sub>PO<sub class="frac">4</sub></label>
answers.B: <label>B. HPO<sub class="frac">4</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup> and NaH<sub class="frac">2</sub>PO<sub class="frac">4</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup></label>
answers.C: <label>C. HC<sub class="frac">3</sub>H<sub class="frac">2</sub>O<sub class="frac">2</sub> and NaC<sub class="frac">3</sub>H<sub class="frac">2</sub>O<sub class="frac">2</sub></label>
answers.D: <label>D. NaOH and HC<sub class="frac">2</sub>H<sub class="frac">3</sub>O<sub class="frac">2</sub></label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Strong acids and bases do not make good buffers, so that eliminates (A) and (D). Of the remaining choices, a solution of H2PO4- would with a Ka in the 10-13 range would have a [H+] of . That would put [H+] between 10-6 and 10-7, yielding a pH in the required range.

content: A solution contains a mixture of four different compounds: KCl(aq), Fe(NO3)3(aq), MgSO4(aq), and N2H4(aq). Which of these compounds would be easiest to separate via distillation?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Distillation involves the boiling off of substances with different boiling points. The other three compounds are all ionic, meaning that in solution they are free ions. If we were to boil off all of the N2H4 and the water, the remaining ions would all mix together to form multiple precipitates. However, by heating the solution to a boiling point greater than that of N2H4 and lower than that of water, the N2H4 can be collected in a separate flask.

content:
Identify the three gases represented on the Maxwell-Boltzmann diagram above. Assume all gases are at the same temperature.

I    II    III

answers.A: <label>A.    H<sub class="frac">2</sub>    N<sub class="frac">2</sub>    F<sub class="frac">2</sub></label>
answers.B: <label>B.    H<sub class="frac">2</sub>    F<sub class="frac">2</sub>    N<sub class="frac">2</sub></label>
answers.C: <label>C.    F<sub class="frac">2</sub>    N<sub class="frac">2</sub>    H<sub class="frac">2</sub></label>
answers.D: <label>D.    N<sub class="frac">2</sub>    F<sub class="frac">2</sub>    H<sub class="frac">2</sub></label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C At identical temperatures, the gases would all have identical amounts of kinetic energy. In order for that to happen, the gas with the lowest mass (H2) would have to have the highest average velocity, and the gas with the highest mass (F2) would have to have the lowest average velocity.

content: A sample of solid MgCl2 would be most soluble in which of the following solutions?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Like dissolves like, so ionic substances dissolve best in ionic compounds, eliminating (B). Both (C) and (D) share an ion with MgCl2. Via the common ion effect and Le Châtelier's principle that would reduce the solubility of the MgCl2 in those solutions. The best choice is (A).

content: Most transition metals share a common oxidation state of +2. Which of the following best explains why?

answers.A: <label>A. Transition metals all have a minimum of two unpaired electrons.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Transition metals have unstable configurations and are very reactive.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Transition metals tend to gain electrons when reacting with other elements.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The outermost s-block electrons in a transition metal tend to be lost before the d-block electrons do. Additionally, the other options do not accurately describe the properties of transition metals.

content:
2Ag+(aq) + Fe(s) → 2Ag(s) + Fe2+(aq)

Which of the following would cause an increase in potential in the voltaic cell described by the above reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Adding or removing a solid would not cause any equilibrium shift. Decreasing the concentration of the Fe2+ causes a shift to the right, which would increase the potential of the cell.

content:
Consider the Lewis structures for the following molecules:
CO2, CO32-, NO2-, and NO3-

Which molecule would have the shortest bonds?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The following Lewis structures are necessary to answer questions 38-41:

CO2 has a bond order of 2, which exceeds the order of the other structures. Remember that a higher bond order corresponds with shorter and stronger bonds.

content:
Consider the Lewis structures for the following molecules:
CO2, CO32-, NO2-, and NO3-

Which molecules are best represented by multiple resonance structures?

answers.A: <label>A. CO<sub class="frac">2</sub> and CO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup></label>
answers.B: <label>B. NO<sub class="frac">2</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup> and NO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup></label>
answers.C: <label>C. CO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup> and NO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup></label>
answers.D: <label>D. CO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup>, NO<sub class="frac">2</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup> and NO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup></label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Except for CO2, the other three molecules all display resonance.

content:
Consider the Lewis structures for the following molecules:
CO2, CO32-, NO2-, and NO3-

Which molecule or molecules exhibit sp2 hybridization around the central atom?

answers.A: <label>A. CO<sub class="frac">2</sub> and CO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup></label>
answers.B: <label>B. NO<sub class="frac">2</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup> and NO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup></label>
answers.C: <label>C. CO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup> and NO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup></label>
answers.D: <label>D. CO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">2-</sup>, NO<sub class="frac">2</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup> and NO<sub class="frac">3</sub><sup class="frac">-</sup></label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D All three of those structures have three electron domains, and thus sp2 hybridization.

content:
Consider the Lewis structures for the following molecules:
CO2, CO32-, NO2-, and NO3-

Which molecule would have the smallest bond angle between terminal atoms?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The bond angle of NO2- would be less than that of NO3- or CO32- because the unbonded pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom reduces the overall bond angle.

content:
NH4+(aq) + NO2- (aq) → N2(g) + 2H2O(l)

Increasing the temperature of the above reaction will increase the rate of reaction. Which of the following is NOT a reason that increased temperature increases reaction rate?

answers.A: <label>A. The reactants will be more likely to overcome the activation energy.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The number of collisions between reactant molecules will increase.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A greater distribution of reactant molecules will have high velocities.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Alternate reaction pathways become available at higher temperatures.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Even if this were true, any pathways that become available at higher temperatures would be less likely to be taken than the original pathway.

content: Which of the following diagrams best represents what is happening on a molecular level when NaCl dissolves in water?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The Na+ cations would be attracted to the negative (oxygen) end of the water molecules and the Cl- anions would be attracted to the positive (hydrogen) end. Additionally, Na+ ions are smaller than Cl- ions as they have less filled energy levels.

content: Nitrous acid, HNO2, has a pKa value of 3.3. If a solution of nitrous acid is found to have a pH of 4.2, what can be said about the concentration of the conjugate acid/base pair found in solution?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B In this case, the pH is greater than the pKa. This means that there will be more conjugate base present in solution than the original acid. The conjugate base of HNO2 is NO2-.

content: Which of the following processes is an irreversible reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Combustion reactions are irreversible, while the other reactions are examples of acid-base, dissolution, and oxidation-reduction, all of which are reversible in this case.

content:
A sample of H2S gas is placed in an evacuated, sealed container and heated until the following decomposition reaction occurs at 1000 K:
2H2S(g) → 2H2(g) + S2(g)         Kc = 1.0 × 10-6

Which of the following represents the equilibrium constant for this reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Equilibrium is always products over reactants, and coefficients in a balanced equilibrium reaction become exponents in the equilibrium expression.

content:
A sample of H2S gas is placed in an evacuated, sealed container and heated until the following decomposition reaction occurs at 1000 K:
2H2S(g) → 2H2(g) + S2(g)         Kc = 1.0 × 10-6

Which of the following graphs would best represent the change in concentration of the various species involved in the reaction over time?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The concentration of the H2S will decrease exponentially until it reaches a constant value. The concentrations of the two products will increase exponentially (the H2 twice as quickly as the S2) until reaching equilibrium.

content:
A sample of H2S gas is placed in an evacuated, sealed container and heated until the following decomposition reaction occurs at 1000 K:
2H2S(g) → 2H2(g) + S2(g)         Kc = 1.0 × 10-6

Which option best describes what will immediately occur to the reaction rates if the pressure on the system is increased after it has reached equilibrium?

answers.A: <label>A. The rate of both the forward and reverse reactions will increase.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The rate of the forward reaction will increase while the rate of the reverse reaction decreases.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The rate of the forward reaction will decrease while the rate of the reverse reaction increases.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Neither the rate of the forward nor reverse reactions will change.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Increasing the pressure causes a shift towards the side with fewer gas molecules-in this case, a shift to the left. This means the reverse reaction rate increases while the forward reaction rate decreases.

content:
A sample of H2S gas is placed in an evacuated, sealed container and heated until the following decomposition reaction occurs at 1000 K:
2H2S(g) → 2H2(g) + S2(g)         Kc = 1.0 × 10-6

If, at a given point in the reaction, the value for the reaction quotient Q is determined to be 2.5 × 10-8, which of the following is occurring?

answers.A: <label>A. The concentration of the reactant is decreasing while the concentration of the products is increasing.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The concentration of the reactant is increasing while the concentration of the products is decreasing.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The system has passed the equilibrium point and the concentration of all species involved in the reaction will remain constant.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The concentrations of all species involved are changing at the same rate.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The reaction will progress until Q = Kc. If Q < Kc, the numerator of the expression (the products) will continue to increase while the denominator (the reactant) increases until equilibrium is established.

content:
A sample of H2S gas is placed in an evacuated, sealed container and heated until the following decomposition reaction occurs at 1000 K:
2H2S(g) → 2H2(g) + S2(g)         Kc = 1.0 × 10-6

As the reaction progresses at a constant temperature of 1,000K, how does the value for the Gibbs free energy constant for the reaction change?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A If the temperature is constant, then the equilibrium constant K is unchanged. Via DG = -RT ln K, if K and T are both constant then so is the value for ΔG.

content: An unknown substance is found to have a high melting point. In addition, it is a poor conductor of electricity and does not dissolve in water. The substance most likely contains
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C An ionic substance would dissolve in water, and a nonpolar covalent substance would have a low melting point. A metallic substance would be a good conductor. The only type of bonding that meets all the criteria is covalent network bonding.

content: Which of the following best explains why the ionization of atoms can occur during photoelectron spectroscopy, even though ionization is not a thermodynamically favored process?

answers.A: <label>A. It is an exothermic process due to the release of energy as an electron is liberated from the Coulombic attraction holding it to the nucleus.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The entropy of the system increases due to the separation of the electron from its atom.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Energy contained in the light can be used to overcome the Coulombic attraction between electrons and the nucleus.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The products of the ionization are at a lower energy state than the reactants.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Light contains energy (via E = hv), and that energy can be used to cause a reaction.

content: The above diagrams shows the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide in a sealed container in the presence of a catalyst. What is the overall order for the reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B In 200 seconds, half of the original sample decayed. In another 200 seconds, half of the remaining sample decayed. This demonstrates a first order reaction.

content:
One of the resonance structures for the nitrite ion is shown above. What is the formal charge on each atom?

Ox &nbps;&nbps; N &nbps;&nbps; Oy
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Ox has 6 valence electrons and 7 assigned electrons: 6 - 7 = -1. Both Oy and the N atoms have the same number of valence and assigned electrons, making their formal charges zero.

content:
Atoms of four elements are examined: carbon, nitrogen, neon, and sulfur.

Atoms of which element would have the strongest magnetic moment?
