Taking the square root gives

content:
N2O4(g) decomposes into NO2(g) according to the equation above. A pure sample of N2O4(g) is placed into a rigid, evacuated 0.500 L container. The initial pressure of the N2O4(g) is 760 atm. The temperature is held constant until the N2O4(g) reaches equilibrium with its decomposition products. The figure below shows how the pressure of the system changes while reaching equilibrium.

Which is a correct description of the partial pressures of N2O4 and NO2?

answers.A: <label>A. The partial pressures of both N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> are increasing.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The partial pressures of both N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> and NO<sub>2</sub> are decreasing.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The partial pressure of N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> is increasing twice as fast as that of NO<sub>2</sub> is decreasing.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The partial pressure of NO<sub>2</sub> is increasing twice as fast as that of N<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> is decreasing.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) When the reaction occurs, the N2O4 must decrease and the NO2 must increase. (D) is the only response that expresses this fact.

content:
N2O4(g) decomposes into NO2(g) according to the equation above. A pure sample of N2O4(g) is placed into a rigid, evacuated 0.500 L container. The initial pressure of the N2O4(g) is 760 atm. The temperature is held constant until the N2O4(g) reaches equilibrium with its decomposition products. The figure below shows how the pressure of the system changes while reaching equilibrium.

The pressure versus time curve can be used to evaluate

answers.A: <label>A. the kinetics of the reaction from the rising part and the equilibrium constant from the horizontal part</label>
answers.B: <label>B. only the kinetics of the reaction from the rising part</label>
answers.C: <label>C. only the equilibrium constant from the horizontal part</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) All responses are partially correct. (B), (C), and (D) incorrectly state that "only" that parameter can be determined.

content:
N2O4(g) decomposes into NO2(g) according to the equation above. A pure sample of N2O4(g) is placed into a rigid, evacuated 0.500 L container. The initial pressure of the N2O4(g) is 760 atm. The temperature is held constant until the N2O4(g) reaches equilibrium with its decomposition products. The figure below shows how the pressure of the system changes while reaching equilibrium.

What will the final pressure be if this reaction goes to completion? Based on the data, does this reaction go to completion?

answers.A: <label>A. 760 torr; yes, the reaction goes to completion because this is the given pressure.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. 900 torr; yes, the reaction goes to completion because it reached equilibrium.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. 1520 torr; no, the reaction does not go to completion because it is not 1520 torr when the reaction stopped.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. 2280 torr; no, the reaction does not go to completion because it is not 2280 torr when the reaction stopped.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The correct pressure is 1520 torr if the reaction goes to completion because the reaction shows that there will be twice the moles of product compared with reactant if all the reactant is consumed. We also conclude the reaction does not go to completion since that pressure is not reached.

content:
N2O4(g) decomposes into NO2(g) according to the equation above. A pure sample of N2O4(g) is placed into a rigid, evacuated 0.500 L container. The initial pressure of the N2O4(g) is 760 atm. The temperature is held constant until the N2O4(g) reaches equilibrium with its decomposition products. The figure below shows how the pressure of the system changes while reaching equilibrium.

What is the appropriate combination of numbers for calculating Kp?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The pressure of N2O4 will change by some amount, -x. The amount of NO2 increases by +2x. Therefore, the pressure in the vessel will be

P = 960 torr = 760 torr -x + 2x = 760 torr + x

Calculating for x gives

960 - 760 = 200 torr

Finally, the pressure of N2O4 is 760 - x = 560 torr and the pressure of NO2 is 2x = 2 Ã— 200 = 400 torr. Then we must convert torr to atm by dividing by 760 torr/atm before entering values into the equation. Only (B) has the proper form to fit the chemical equation.

content:
N2O4(g) decomposes into NO2(g) according to the equation above. A pure sample of N2O4(g) is placed into a rigid, evacuated 0.500 L container. The initial pressure of the N2O4(g) is 760 atm. The temperature is held constant until the N2O4(g) reaches equilibrium with its decomposition products. The figure below shows how the pressure of the system changes while reaching equilibrium.

Which diagram is an appropriate description of the system if more NO2(g) is rapidly injected, at time = 0, into the container after equilibrium is established?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) We expect to see a sharp rise in pressure when more N2O4 is injected into the system. Then there will be a slower rise due to the slow conversion of N2O4 to NO2.

content:
Formation of a solution can often be visualized as a three-step process.

Step 1. Solvent molecules are separated from each other to make space for the solute.

Step 2. Solute molecules are separated so they fit into spaces in the solvent

Step 3. Separated solute and solvent are brought together filling in the spaces.

All of the fundamental principles below are important in understanding the formation of solutions except which one?

answers.A: <label>A. Starting at equilibrium, moving particles apart while in the solid or equilibrium phases requires added energy proportional to the attractive forces.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Bringing particles together releases energy in proportion to their attractive forces.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The total of the energies in steps 1 to 3 indicates if a solution will form.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Molecules with similar molecular masses are required to form solutions.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Molecular mass is not an important factor by itself in solution formation.

content: Bromine has a normal boiling point of 59 째C, and iodine boils at 184 째C. The I2 molecule is much larger than Br2 (atomic radii are 114 and 133 pm, respectively). Which is the best reason for the large difference in boiling points?

answers.A: <label>A. Bromine is a liquid and boils; iodine is a solid and sublimes.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The intramolecular bonds in I<sub>2</sub> are much weaker than those in Br<sub>2</sub>.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The I<sub>2</sub> electron clouds are much more polarizable than the Br<sub>2</sub> electron clouds, resulting in much stronger London forces.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The mass of iodine is much greater than the mass of bromine.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Polarizability of the electron cloud to form instantaneous dipoles and induced dipole-induced dipole interactions explains the difference in boiling points.

content: Ethanoic acid (HC2H3O2 or CH3CO2H or CH3COOH) has a much lower vapor pressure than ethanol (CH3CH2OH). What is the most reasonable explanation?

answers.A: <label>A. The polarizability of two oxygen atoms increases the London forces of attraction in ethanoic acid compared with ethanol.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Hydrogen bonding in ethanoic acid is the strongest attractive force and is mainly responsible for the observed data.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Ethanol has an –OH group and can hydrogen bond; therefore, the London forces must cause the effect.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Both ethanol and ethanoic acid have an –OH, so the difference is the dipole of the second oxygen that increases the attractive forces.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Ethanoic acid molecules strongly hydrogen bond so that most molecules are part of dimers.

content:
The synthesis of solid lead(II) sulfide can be expressed in the equation

Which statement about this reaction as temperature is increased is most reasonable?

answers.A: <label>A. This reaction will become thermodynamically favored because the entropy change is expected to be positive.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. This reaction will always be thermodynamically favored because the entropy change is expected to be positive.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. This reaction will always be thermodynamically unfavored because the entropy change is expected to be positive.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. This reaction will become thermodynamically unfavored because the entropy change is expected to be negative.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The standard Gibbs free energy charge must be negative for a thermodynamically favored process. The enthalpy is negative. So at low temperatures, the reaction will be thermodynamically favored. Since the entropy change is expected to be negative, the temperature-entropy change term in the Gibbs equation becomes increasingly positive, resulting in the reaction becoming thermodynamically unfavorable at higher temperatures.

Correct Answer: A

content:
The synthesis of solid lead(II) sulfide can be expressed in the equation

If 5.0 g of lead and 1.0 g of sulfur are reacted according to the equation above, what will be left in measurable amounts (more than 1 mg) in the reaction vessel?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) We can estimate the moles of Pb = 5 g / 207 g/mol = 1/40. Estimating the moles of S gives 1 g / 32 g/mol = 1/30 mol S. Since 1/30 is larger than 1/40, we will have an excess of sulfur. Remember that the reaction is 1 Pb to 1 S. If sulfur is in excess, lead will not be in the vessel at the end.

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The elements close to the upper right of the periodic table all have exothermic electron affinities, so ΔH (4) is likely to be exothermic. Combining ions to form the product, as shown in ΔH (5), is always exothermic.

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

(A) This is the reaction forming the crystal lattice. Since some define lattice energy as the energy needed to separate ions in the crystal and others define it as the energy released when combining these ions, the question was worded to fit either definition.

content:
Questions refer to the cell diagrams and their corresponding E°cell values for the three galvanic cells listed in the table below.

The chemical reaction occurring in the first galvanic cell is

Zn + Pb2+ → Zn2+ + Pb

What is the standard cell potential for galvanic cell 3 depicted in the table above?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The reaction for the first cell is given as

Zn + Pb2+ → Zn2+ + Pb

For the second cell, the reaction is

Mg + Pb2+ → Mg2+ + Pb

By reversing the first reaction, adding the two reactions, and canceling the lead, we get the third cell

Mg + Zn2+ → Mg2+ + Zn

The standard cell potentials are likewise subtracted: E°cell = 2.24 - 0.63 = +1.61V. The standard cell potential for this cell, as written, is negative.

content:
Questions refer to the cell diagrams and their corresponding E°cell values for the three galvanic cells listed in the table below.

The chemical reaction occurring in the first galvanic cell is

Zn + Pb2+ → Zn2+ + Pb

What is the chemical reaction under study in galvanic cell 3?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This was shown in answer 42:

Mg + Zn2+ → Mg2+ + Zn

content:
Questions refer to the cell diagrams and their corresponding E°cell values for the three galvanic cells listed in the table below.

The chemical reaction occurring in the first galvanic cell is

Zn + Pb2+ → Zn2+ + Pb

If the concentration of Mg2+ is changed from 1.0 M to 0.1 M in the galvanic cells above, what will happen to the observed cell voltages in galvanic cells 2 and 3?

answers.A: <label>A. The voltage in both galvanic cells 2 and 3 will increase.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The voltage will decrease in both galvanic cells 2 and 3.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The voltage in galvanic cell 2 will increase and will decrease in galvanic cell 3.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The voltage in galvanic cell 3 will increase and will decrease in galvanic cell 2.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) As discussed in Example 13.6 and the Solution for Exercise 13.5, if E°cell is positive and the product concentration is larger than the reactant concentration, the voltage will decrease toward zero. In this case the product concentration is less than the reactant concentration, so the voltage will increase. This will happen in both cells 2 and 3.

content:
Questions refer to the cell diagrams and their corresponding E°cell values for the three galvanic cells listed in the table below.

The chemical reaction occurring in the first galvanic cell is

Zn + Pb2+ → Zn2+ + Pb

Rank Mg, Pb, and Zn from the metal that is easiest to oxidize to the metal that is the most difficult to oxidize.
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Magnesium will be oxidized by both lead and zinc. So magnesium is easiest to oxidize. Since zinc is oxidized by lead, zinc is the second easiest to oxidize.

content:
Carbon has an atomic radius of 77 pm and a first ionization energy of 1086 kJ/mol.

Based on periodic trends and the data given above, what are the most probable values for the ionization energy and atomic radius of nitrogen?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The periodic trends inform us that the radius of nitrogen is expected to be less than that of the preceding carbon. Additionally, the ionization energy increases from left to right across a period, so the ionization energy for nitrogen should be larger than that of carbon.

content: Dissolving one mole of each of the following compounds in water results in solutions with different pH values. Under those conditions, which of the following acids will have the highest percentage ionization?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Perchloric acid is a strong acid and is essentially 100 percent ionized.

content: Based on the data in the table above, which of the following substances has lowest viscosity?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The lowest boiling point points to the lowest attractive forces and thus the lowest viscosity.

content: Based on periodic relationships, the concepts related to bond strength, and the concept relating bond strength to acid strength, which of the following correctly predicts the strength of binary acids from strongest to weakest?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) For binary acids, those with longer bond lengths, and thus weaker bonds, are stronger acids.

content: Chlorine is often used to oxidize other substances. It makes a good bleach because it can oxidize many colored compounds. If chlorine is not available, what other substance can be used for oxidizing substances?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The first three substances most commonly get oxidized and cause other substances to be reduced, the opposite of what we want. KMnO4 is a recognized oxidizer and can replace chlorine in many cases.

content:
Vitamin C is oxidized slowly to dehydroascorbic acid by the oxygen in air. It is catalyzed by ions such as Cu2+ and Fe3+. The reaction can be followed by measuring the ultraviolet absorbance at 243 nm.

Which of the following is the best interpretation of the data given above?

answers.A: <label>A. The data support a first-order reaction.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The data support a second-order reaction.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The data support a zero-order reaction.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The data show a linear trend for ln A vs. time. This is characteristic of a first-order reaction.

content: A new compound is synthesized and found to be a monoprotic acid with a molar mass of 248 g/mol. When 0.0050 mol of this acid are dissolved in 0.500 L of water, the pH is measured as 3.89. What is the pKa of this acid?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) We can write [H+] = 10-3.89, which is also equal to [A]

Ka= [H+][A-]/[HA] = (10-3.89)(10-3.89)/(10-2)

Recall that we add exponents in the numerator and subtract the exponents in the denominator. The resulting exponent will be -3.89 + (-3.89) - (-2) = 5.78. So Ka= 10-5.78. To get the pKa, take the negative of the logarithm of 10-5.78. The result is 5.78.

content: Which of the following particulate diagrams best represents the reaction of gaseous sulfur (black dots) with oxygen (white circles) to form sulfur dioxide?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Only this response is stoichiometrically correct and obeys the law of conservation of mass. We have 5O2 and 7S atoms. This gives 5SO2 and 2S left over, as shown.

content: Nitrous acid is a weak acid, while nitric acid is a much stronger acid because

answers.A: <label>A. the nitrogen in nitric acid is more electronegative than the nitrogen in nitrous acid</label>
answers.B: <label>B. nitric acid has more oxygen atoms in its formula</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the –O–H bonds in nitric acid are much weaker than in nitrous acid due to the electron withdrawing of more oxygen atoms on nitric acid</label>
answers.D: <label>D. nitric acid has the hydrogen atoms bound directly to the nitrogen atom</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Weaker bonds to hydrogen mean stronger acids.

content: A student has a liter of a 0.100 M solution of a strong acid. To prepare a buffer, this should be mixed with
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) A buffer must contain a conjugate acid-base pair. The only solutions that can possibly produce this combination in this case is the strong acid neutralizing part of a weak base solution.

content: The photoelectron data for sodium is shown above. Which of the following statements is true about this data?

answers.D: <label>D. Peaks with the lowest energies are due to electrons closest to the nucleus.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

(A) All the other statements are misreading the spectroscopy data.

content: Identify the Brønsted-Lowry conjugate acid-base pair in the following list.
explanation:

(C) This pair differs by the one H+ that is required in the definition of a Brønsted-Lowry conjugate acid-base pair.

content: Chemical reactions can be classified as either heterogeneous or homogeneous. Which of the following equations below is best classified as a heterogeneous reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

(D) This is the only reaction showing two different phases.

content: Which of the reactions below will not be thermodynamically favored at all temperatures?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

(C) The Gibbs free energy can never be negative using these numbers.

content:

Correct Answer: A

content: An experiment was performed to determine the moles of carbon dioxide gas formed (collected over water) when an acid reacts with limestone. To do this, a piece of dry limestone was weighed. Then carbon dioxide was collected until the limestone disappeared. The atmospheric pressure was measured at 0.965 atm. The temperature was 295 K. The volume of CO2 was measured to the nearest mL and corrected for the vapor pressure of water. The student continuously got low results from what was expected. Can you suggest why?

answers.C: <label>C. Carbon dioxide is rather soluble in water.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Perhaps there was not enough acid to dissolve all the limestone.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) When collecting a gas over a liquid, the solubility of the gas in the liquid must be taken into account.

content: Choose the description of the point on the distribution curve that is the most plausible.
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) At point C, which is a little beyond the maximum, the average kinetic energy is directly proportional to temperature.

content: Your supervisor asks you to determine the enthalpy of a certain chemical reaction. Which would you do?

answers.B: <label>B. Use a bomb calorimeter to measure the heat of the reaction.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Use a solution calorimeter such as a coffee-cup calorimeter to measure the heat.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Use a photoelectron spectrometer to measure the energies of all atoms in the compounds, and use Hess's law to add them.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Enthalpy is defined as the heat of reaction at constant pressure. The coffee-cup calorimeter operates at constant pressure (equal to the current atmospheric pressure) and is the method of choice.

content: A 25 g sample of a solid was heated to 100 °C and then quickly transferred to an insulated container holding 100 g of water at 26 °C. The temperature of the mixture rose to reach a final temperature of 37 °C. Which of the following can be concluded?

answers.A: <label>A. The sample lost more thermal energy than the water gained because the sample temperature changed more than the water temperature did.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Even though the sample temperature changed more than the water temperature did, the sample lost the same amount of thermal energy as the water gained.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The sample temperature changed more than the water temperature did; therefore the heat capacity of the sample must be greater than the heat capacity of the water.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The final temperature is less than the average starting temperatures; therefore the equilibrium constant must be less than 1.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This response obeys the law of conservation of energy.

content: Three 1-liter flasks are connected to a 3-liter flask by valves as shown in the diagram above. The 3-liter flask has the relative number of helium atoms as indicated. At the start, the entire system is at 585K. The first flask contains oxygen; the second contains hydrogen, and the third contains nitrogen. The pressure of hydrogen is 3.00 atm. The number of gas molecules is proportional to their representations in the flasks. If the valves are all opened, what will be the pressure in the system? Assume the connections have negligible volume.
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) 6 particles is equivalent to 3 atmospheres. We have 24 particles and 6 liters, or 4 particles per liter. That is 4/6 or 2/3 of the original pressure, or 2.0 atm.

content: A mass spectrum of a naturally occurring sample of an element is shown above. What is the element?

answers.D: <label>D. There are two peaks, so there must be two compounds.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Mass 35 is about 75 percent and mass 37 is about 25 percent. Calculate

(0.75)(35) +(0.25)(37) = 26.25 + 9.25 = 35.5

This mass is very close to that of chlorine.

content:
The above graph shows a titration curve of a weak base titrated with a strong acid. The pH was measured with a pH meter after small volumes of 0.200 M HNO3 were added to 50.0 mL of a weak base. Data from that experiment are shown in that graph.

Which of the following describes the base that is being titrated?

answers.D: <label>D. The concentration of the base cannot be determined without knowing its molar mass.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Using the equation MacidVacid = MbaseVbase, the molarity of the base will be MacidVacid/Vbase. The ratio of the volumes is 22.5 mL/50.0 mL, which is less than one-half. So the molarity of the base is less than one-half of the acid or less than 0.100 M.

content:
The above graph shows a titration curve of a weak base titrated with a strong acid. The pH was measured with a pH meter after small volumes of 0.200 M HNO3 were added to 50.0 mL of a weak base. Data from that experiment are shown in that graph.

At what point on this curve does the solution display the least buffering capacity?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) At the end point, or inflection point, the pH changes the most with a given amount of titrant.

content:

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The inflection point is the end point. That is the only point where stoichiometric calculations can be made.

content:
The above graph shows a titration curve of a weak base titrated with a strong acid. The pH was measured with a pH meter after small volumes of 0.200 M HNO3 were added to 50.0 mL of a weak base. Data from that experiment are shown in that graph.

If the student uses a pH indicator that changes color from pH 8 to 6, which statement best characterizes the expected observations?

answers.A: <label>A. The color will change slowly, and the end point volume will be low.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The observed color change will be distinct, and the calculated molarity of the base will be accurate.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The color will change slowly, and the calculated molarity of the base will be low.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The observed color change will be distinct, but the calculated molarity of the base will be high.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) We see that the color will start changing well before the end point, and it will take several mL to change. So the color change will be gradual. This color change also occurs before the end point, so the volume will be low.

content:
The above graph shows a titration curve of a weak base titrated with a strong acid. The pH was measured with a pH meter after small volumes of 0.200 M HNO3 were added to 50.0 mL of a weak base. Data from that experiment are shown in that graph.

Which arrow points to the place where the slope (ΔpH/Δvol) of the titration curve is the smallest?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The pH change is the smallest at the midpoint, incidentally, where the buffer strength is the highest.

content:
Four different 0.0100 M acid solutions were prepared, and their pH values were recorded on a laptop computer. One of the solutions contains more than just an acid. At the point designated as "add," all four solutions are diluted with an equal volume of water. The bottom line represents solution 1, and the top line represents solution 4.

Using the data in the graph, which of the solutions does not contain just an acid dissolved in water?

answers.A: <label>A. Solution 4 because the pH does not change upon dilution</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Solution 1 because the pH changes too much</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Solutions 2 and 3 because the pH did not change enough</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Solution 4, which must be pure water since the pH does not change</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) A buffer pH does not change on dilution, and the problem told us that one solution contains more than just an acid. This solution must contain a conjugate acid-base pair.

content:
Four different 0.0100 M acid solutions were prepared, and their pH values were recorded on a laptop computer. One of the solutions contains more than just an acid. At the point designated as "add," all four solutions are diluted with an equal volume of water. The bottom line represents solution 1, and the top line represents solution 4.

Using the data presented in the graph and the experiment that was performed, which of the weak acids is the weakest?

answers.A: <label>A. Solution 1 because its pH changed the most</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Solution 4 because the pH did not change at all</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Since we know that solution 4 is a buffer, it is a mixture of the three other solutions. The weakest acid must give the highest pH; therefore, we arrive at solution 3 as the answer.

content:

content: Chemists often ascribe the macroscopic properties of solids to the underlying microscopic structure. Silicon carbide is almost as hard and brittle as diamond. The solid state structure of silicon carbide is often described as

content: Which is the easiest way to burn a silver coin?

answers.A: <label>A. Hold the silver coin with crucible tongs, and heat strongly in the flame of a Bunsen burner.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Use the method in (A), but use an oxyacetylene torch to reach a higher temperature.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Grind the silver coin into very small, dust-sized particles, and spray the particles into a Bunsen burner flame.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Dissolve the silver coin in acid, precipitate the hydroxide, and heat in a Bunsen burner flame to make the oxide.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Burning of a solid metal is actually a simple kinetics question. When the metal is ground to a powder, it burns easily in a flame.

content:
Note that in addition to the data in the table, the gases are held in separate, identical, rigid vessels.

answers.A: <label>A. All have the same density since the temperatures are all the same.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

PV = nRT = (g/molar mass)RT.

Rearrange to get

P(molar mass)/T = (g/V)R

where g/V is the density.

content:

The reaction between sulfur and oxygen, written in equation form above, can be interpreted in all of the following ways except

content: Which hydrogen in butanoic acid, shown above, will ionize and why?

answers.B: <label>B. Hydrogen #1: its bond to the rest of the molecule is the weakest due to the electronegativity of two nearby oxygen atoms.</label>

content: Butanoic acid C4H8O2, shown above, gives rancid butter its foul smell. It has a Ka = 1.5 × 10-5. If a 0.0100 M solution of butanoic acid is prepared, the expected pH will be in which one of the following pH ranges?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This solution is concentrated enough so that all the assumptions used in calculating pH will work. In particular, [H+] = (Ka MHA)1/2-. Solve this equation

[H+] = ((1.5 × 10-5)(0.0100))1/2 = (1.5 × 10-7)1/2 = (15 × 10-8)1/2

The square root of 15 is approximately 4, and the square root of 10-8 is 10-4. Since [H+] = 4 × 10-4 and this number is between 10-4 and 10-3, we know the pH must be between pH 3 and 4.

content:

Which of the following is a molecular equation for the reaction described above?
explanation:

content:
Tl+(aq) + Cl-(aq) → TlCl(s)
A chemist mixes a dilute solution of thallium perchlorate with a dilute solution of potassium chloride to precipitate thallium chloride (Ksp = 1.9 × 10-4).

If equal volumes of 2.0 millimolar solutions are mixed, which of the following particulate views represents the experiment after the reactants are mixed thoroughly and solids are given time to precipitate?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) No precipitate will form. Ksp = 1.9 × 10-4 = [Tl+][Cl-]. Calculating the product of the two ions after dilution is (0.00100 M)(0.00100 M) = 1.0 × 10-6. This value is smaller than the Ksp, so no precipitate forms.

content:
Tl+(aq) + Cl-(aq) → TlCl(s)
A chemist mixes a dilute solution of thallium perchlorate with a dilute solution of potassium chloride to precipitate thallium chloride (Ksp = 1.9 × 10-4).

Within a factor of 10, what is the approximate molar solubility of thallium chloride in distilled water?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Using s for the molar solubility, the equation becomes

Ksp = 1.9 × 10-4 = [Tl+][Cl-] = s × s = s2

Since s is the square root of 1.9 × 10-4, s is a little more than 10-2 molar.

content:
SO2(g) is produced in the combustion of coal, oil, gasoline and many other natural products. In the atmosphere, it reacts with oxygen to form SO3(g) via the equation above. A pure sample of SO3(g) is placed into a rigid, evacuated 0.500 L container. The initial pressure of the SO3(g) is 760 atm. The temperature is held constant until the system reaches equilibrium. The figure below shows how the pressure of the system changes in reaching equilibrium.

Why does the pressure rise in this experiment?

answers.A: <label>A. Actually, the pressure should decrease since three moles of gas are producing two moles in the reaction.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. SO<sub>2</sub> is polar, resulting in more effective collisions with the container walls.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The nonpolar sulfur trioxide becomes the polar sulfur dioxide, thus increasing the number of collisions per second.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Two moles of SO<sub>3</sub> are producing three moles of gas, increasing the particles in the container colliding with the walls.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The number of moles increases while the volume and temperature are held constant. Therefore, the pressure will increase.

(D) There will be an initial sharp rise in pressure, but the subsequent reaction of SO2 with O2 will slowly reduce the pressure. The equilibrium pressure will be higher than before the injection since material was added to the system.

content:
SO2(g) is produced in the combustion of coal, oil, gasoline and many other natural products. In the atmosphere, it reacts with oxygen to form SO3(g) via the equation above. A pure sample of SO3(g) is placed into a rigid, evacuated 0.500 L container. The initial pressure of the SO3(g) is 760 atm. The temperature is held constant until the system reaches equilibrium. The figure below shows how the pressure of the system changes in reaching equilibrium.

Why are SO2(g) and SO3(g) pollutants to be concerned about?

answers.A: <label>A. They contain yellow sulfur that causes jaundice.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. They both are acid anhydrides, forming H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>3</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, which are a major part of acid rain.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. They both have resonance structures that lead to free radicals that cause cancer.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They create the brown layer of smog seen over many cities and destroy O<sub>3</sub>, which is essential for life.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Acid rain is a major problem, and sulfur oxides are a large part of that problem.

content: Fluorine has a normal boiling point of 85 K, and chlorine boils at 239 K. The Cl2 molecule is much larger than F2 (atomic radius is 99 pm for chlorine and is 64 pm for fluorine). Which is the best reason for the large difference in boiling points?

answers.A: <label>A. Chlorine has a higher dipole moment than fluorine.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The intramolecular bonds in Cl<sub>2</sub> are much weaker than those in F<sub>2</sub>.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Cl<sub>2</sub> electron clouds are much more polarizable than the F<sub>2</sub> electron clouds, resulting in much stronger London forces.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The mass of chlorine is much greater than the mass of fluorine.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The only attractive forces in this case are London forces, which depend on a polarizable electron cloud.

content: Space-filling representations of carbon tetrachloride and carbon tetrabromide are shown above. The carbon can be seen in the carbon tetrachloride and is hidden by the bromine in carbon tetrabromide. Which of the following is the most reasonable statement? (Assume that the temperatures of CCl4 and CBr4 are the same in these comparisons.)

answers.A: <label>A. CCl<sub>4</sub> has a higher surface tension compared with CBr<sub>4</sub>.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. CCl<sub>4</sub> has a higher vapor pressure compared with CBr<sub>4</sub>.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. CCl<sub>4</sub> has a higher boiling point compared with CBr<sub>4</sub>.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. CCl<sub>4</sub> has a higher viscosity compared with CBr<sub>4</sub>.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) We can deduce that the attractive forces in CBr4 are stronger than those in CCl4 because the bromine electron cloud is much more polarizable than the chlorine atom's electron cloud. Response (B) is the only one that agrees with the attractive forces.

content:
Questions refer to the following formation equation for the reaction synthesizing RbBr(s). This reaction can be separated into a series of steps.

Using Hess's law, which of the following combinations will give the enthalpy for the above reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Combining equation ΔH°(3) from the table with equation ΔH°(4) twice will reproduce the equation needed. Therefore, ΔH° = ΔH°(3) + 2ΔH°(4).

content:

When 1.00 mol of O2(g) is formed from MgO(s) in the reaction above, how much heat is released or absorbed?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) One mole of O2 is twice what the equation will yield (notice ½ O2). So we have to double the heat energy. In addition, making O2 has the reaction going in the reverse direction. So heat must be added (or absorbed from the surroundings) for the reaction to occur.

content:
Questions refer to the following formation equation for the reaction synthesizing RbBr(s). This reaction can be separated into a series of steps.

Which of the steps in the table above are endothermic?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

(B) Any steps that break bonds or intermolecular attractions will be endothermic.

content:
Questions refer to the following formation equation for the reaction synthesizing RbBr(s). This reaction can be separated into a series of steps.

Noting that this reaction goes to completion, producing MgO from the elements, and using the overall chemical equation to estimate the entropy change for this process, which of the following statements is correct?

answers.A: <label>A. The reaction is favorable and is driven by the enthalpy change since the entropy decreases in this process.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The reaction is unfavorable since the entropy change is a large negative value.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The reaction is favorable and is driven by both enthalpy and entropy changes.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The reaction is unfavorable because of the enthalpy and entropy changes.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) We expect the oxygen going from the gas phase to be a decrease in entropy or at the very least a small entropy effect. Therefore, this reaction is totally driven by the heat energy.

content:
Questions refer to the following formation equation for the reaction synthesizing RbBr(s). This reaction can be separated into a series of steps.

If 1.0 g of magnesium and 1.0 g oxygen are reacted, what will be left in measurable amounts (more than 0.10 mg) in the reaction vessel?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Magnesium is the limiting reactant because there are fewer atoms of Mg in 1.0 gram of Mg than there are atoms of O in 1.0 gram of O. The other important point is that 1 Mg reacts with 1 O. As the limiting reactant, there will be no Mg left when the reaction ends.

content:
Questions refer to the galvanic cells represented by cell diagrams and their corresponding cell voltages listed below.

The chemical reaction occurring in galvanic cell 2 is

V + Co2+ → V2+ + Co

What is the standard cell potential for galvanic cell × depicted in the table above?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) We need to reverse the reaction in galvanic cell 2 and add it to galvanic cell 1 to get the reaction in galvanic cell 3. The difference in potentials is the potential (voltage) of galvanic cell 1 minus the potential in galvanic cell 2, or +0.45 volts.

content:

The chemical reaction occurring in galvanic cell 2 is

V + Co2+ → V2+ + Co

What is the chemical reaction under study in galvanic cell 3?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The left side of the cell diagram is always a reduction half-reaction and the right side is always a reduction. Combining the two gives response (C).

content:
Questions refer to the galvanic cells represented by cell diagrams and their corresponding cell voltages listed below.

The chemical reaction occurring in galvanic cell 2 is

V + Co2+ â†’ V2+ + Co

If the concentration of Ti2+ is changed from 1.0 M to 0.1 M in the galvanic cells above, what will happen to the observed cell voltages in galvanic cells 2 and 3?

answers.A: <label>A. The voltage in both galvanic cells 2 and 3 will increase.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The voltage will decrease in both galvanic cells 2 and 3.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The voltage in galvanic cell 2 will increase and will decrease in galvanic cell 3.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The voltage in galvanic cell 3 will increase and will decrease in galvanic cell 2.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Since the standard cell voltage is positive, we know that the equilibrium constant must be greater than 1. If conditions change so Q is greater than 1, the system is approaching equilibrium and the voltage is expected to decrease. If Q is less than 1, the voltage will increase. In this case, Q = 0.1, so the voltage will increase in galvanic cells 1 and 3.

content:
Questions refer to the galvanic cells represented by cell diagrams and their corresponding cell voltages listed below.

The chemical reaction occurring in galvanic cell 2 is

V + Co2+ â†’ V2+ + Co

Rank the three metals from the metal that is easiest to oxidize to the metal that is the most difficult to oxidize.
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) In galvanic cells 1 and 3, Ti is oxidized by both Co and V. In galvanic cell 2, V is oxidized by Co. So we can write Co > V > Ti for the sequence. The substance that is easiest to oxidize will be the one that is oxidized by both of the other substances. Therefore, Ti is the easiest to oxidize. We need to reverse the sequence to arrange it the way the question asks.

content:
The first ionization energy of sodium is 496 kJ/mol, and its atomic radius is 186 pm.

Based on the information above and your knowledge of periodic trends, which values are the most reasonable for the radius and first ionization energy of the magnesium atom?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Magnesium comes right after sodium in the periodic table. Periodic trends tell us that magnesium atoms will have a smaller radius and a higher ionization potential than sodium due to a higher effective nuclear charge in Mg. Response (A) is the only one that meets that criteria.

content: Dissolving one mole of each of the oxoacids HNO2, HClO4, H2CO3, and H3PO4 in 2.0 L of distilled water results in solutions with different pH values. Arrange these acid solutions from the one with the highest pH to the one with the lowest pH.
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Perchloric acid is the strongest acid listed and therefore has the lowest pH. The relative strengths of the other acids is based on the effect of oxygen atoms and also on the electronegativity of the central atom.

content: Based on the data in the table above, which of the following substances has lowest vapor pressure at any given temperature?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Ethanoic acid has the highest boiling point, indicating the strongest intermolecular attractive forces. The stronger the attractive forces are, the lower the vapor pressure.

content: Based on periodic relationships, the bond strength, and the concept relating bond strength to acid strengths, which of the following correctly predicts the strength of binary acids from strongest to weakest?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The larger the atom is, the longer and weaker the bonds. So H2SE should be the strongest acid in this list.

content: Silver metal, often amalgamated with mercury, is used to reduce substances to a desired oxidation state. If the silver metal amalgam cannot be used because of concerns about mercury, which of the following would be a reasonable and safe substitute?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Magnesium will reduce many metal ions. Sodium metal will also work, but it is hazardous to use.

content: Which of the following particulate diagrams best represents the reaction of carbon with oxygen to form carbon dioxide?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This is the only representation that obeys the law of conservation of mass and also illustrates the limiting reactant situation properly.

content: 0.25 mol of a weak, monoprotic acid is dissolved in 0.25 L of distilled water. The pH was then measured as 4.26. What is the pKa of this weak acid?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) [H+] = [A-] = 10-4.26. The initial concentration of acid is

[HA] = 0.25 mol/0.25 L = 1.0 M. Entering these into the Ka equation gives

The pKa is the negative of the logarithm of 10-8.52, which is 8.52.

content: Sulfurous acid is a weak acid, while sulfuric acid is a much stronger acid because

answers.A: <label>A. the O–H bonds in sulfuric acid are much weaker than in sulfurous acid due to the electron withdrawing of the oxygen atoms on sulfuric acid</label>
answers.B: <label>B. sulfuric acid has more oxygen atoms in its formula</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the sulfur in sulfuric acid is more electronegative than the sulfur in sulfurous acid</label>
answers.D: <label>D. sulfuric acid has the hydrogen atoms bound directly to the sulfur atom</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Weak -O-H bonds make for stronger acids. Electronegativity and lone oxygen atoms just help assess the strength of that bond.

content: To prepare a buffer, all of the following are needed except

answers.B: <label>B. a conjugate acid along with its conjugate base</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a buffer capacity sufficient to react with added acid or base</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Quality deionized water is good enough when preparing buffers.

content:
The photoelectron data for sodium are shown below.

Which of the following statements is not true about this data?

answers.A: <label>A. All 11 electrons are shown in the table.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The 3 valence electrons have the lowest energies at 0.50, 3.67, and 6.84 MJ/mol.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Electrons closest to the nucleus have the lowest energies.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Sodium has only 1 valence electron, not 3.

content: Identify the Brønsted-Lowry conjugate acid-base pair in the following list.
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) The two phosphate species differ by only one H+.

content: Chemical reactions can be classified as either heterogeneous or homogeneous. Which of the following equations below is best classified as a heterogeneous reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) All the other reactions have reactants and products in the same state.

content: Which of the following may need to be balanced using the ion-electron method ?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The ion-electron method is used only to balance redox reactions. Identify a redox reaction by looking for changes in oxidation number. Nitrogen is reduced from an oxidation state of +1 to 0. Carbon is oxidized from -1 to +4.

content: Which of the reactions below will become thermodynamically favored only at high temperatures?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) At low temperatures, enthalpy dominates and results in a positive value for the Gibbs free energy. When the temperature is raised, entropy dominates, making the Gibbs free energy negative.

content:
Sodium azide, NaN3, is a component of automobile airbags. It is useful because it quickly decomposes to generate a large volume of nitrogen gas. The balanced chemical equation for the reaction is:
2 NaN3(s) → 2 Na(s) + 3 N2(g)
There are additional components in the airbag to react with the elemental sodium formed.
Sodium azide is an unstable compound; therefore, it is often necessary to analyze samples as a check of its purity. A chemist is attempting to develop a new analytical, which employs the following reaction:
NaN3(aq) + Na2S(aq) + 3 H2O(l) → N2(g) + NH3(g) + S(s) + 3 NaOH(aq)
The chemist weighed a small flask both with and without a sample of sodium azide and recorded the masses. Next, she connected the flask to the system shown below.
The flask in the middle and the rubber tubing leading to the beaker were completely filled with dilute acid, and then the clamp was removed. Excess sodium sulfide solution was added to the flask containing the sample. The liquid level in the second flask dropped as the generated nitrogen gas displaced the water into the beaker. The system was left intact until gas generation ceased. After the system returned to room temperature, the beaker was raised until the water in the beaker was at the same level as in the second flask. When the liquid levels were the same, the clamp was replaced to prevent further transfer. The chemist completed the following data table in her lab book.

What type of reaction generated the nitrogen gas?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-The reaction is an oxidation-reduction reaction since the sulfide ion undergoes oxidation to elemental sulfur and the azide ion undergoes reduction.

Why must the liquid in the flask be dilute acid?

answers.A: <label>A. Dilute acid is necessary to neutralize the sodium hydroxide formed.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Dilute acid removes ammonia from the gas leaving the nitrogen behind.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Dilute acid causes the reaction to go to completion.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Dilute acid is easier to handle than many other liquids.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-It is necessary to remove the ammonia from the gas; otherwise the part of the volume generated would be due to the ammonia. Since ammonia is a base, it will react with the acid.

What is the partial pressure of the hydrogen gas in the flask?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-The pressure inside the flask is the sum of the partial pressures. Therefore, the pressure of hydrogen gas is the total pressure (748.2 torr) minus the vapor pressure of water (27.0 torr). The leveling of the water in the beaker and flask adjusted the pressure in the flask to the external (barometric) pressure.

answers.A: <label>A. To remove excess water from the rubber tubing and into the beaker</label>

B-When the two liquid levels are the same then the pressures must be equal. In this case, both pressures are equal to the barometric pressure.

If the sample were pure sodium azide, approximately how many moles of nitrogen gas would form?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-The moles of nitrogen gas formed equal the moles of sodium azide reacting (see the balanced chemical equation). If the sample were pure sodium azide, the mass of sodium azide would be (176.604 - 175.245) g = 1.359 g sample (= NaN3). The moles of sodium azide are the mass of sodium azide divided by its molar mass (65.0 g mol-1).

Due to rounding, the actual answer must be a little smaller (0.0209 moles).

Would it be possible to use this experimental setup to study a reaction that produced gaseous sulfur dioxide, SO2? If not, why?

answers.B: <label>B. No, because sulfur dioxide reacts with acids to produce solid sulfur.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. No, because sulfur dioxide is only a gas at very high temperatures.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-Sulfur dioxide gas is soluble in water and, while less soluble in dilute acid, some would still dissolve to give a smaller volume.

content: Which of the labeled arrows in the diagram above represents the strongest intermolecular force of the four indicated?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-This represents an ion-dipole force, which is stronger than a hydrogen bond (B), a dipole-dipole force (C), or a London dispersion force (D).

content: If about 88% of a sample of pure 131I decays in 24 days, what is the approximate half-life of 131I?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-After one half-life, 50% would remain. Another half-life would reduce this by one-half to 25% and a third half-life would reduce the remaining material by 12.5%. Thus, three half-lives = (50 + 25 + 12.5)% = 87.5% decayed. The total amount decayed is 88%. For this reason, 24 days years must be three half-lives of about 8 days each.

content: Cycloalkanes are hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n, where n ≥ 3. If a 0.420 g sample of any alkene is combusted in excess oxygen, how many moles of water will form?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-One mole of a cycloalkane, CnH2n, will form n moles of water. It is possible to determine the value of n by dividing the mass of the cycloalkane by the empirical formula mass (CH2 = 14 g/mol). This gives = 0.040 mol

content: A buffered solution with a pH near 5 is needed for an experiment. Using the above information, which of the combinations would be the best choice to prepare the buffer?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-The best choice to prepare the buffer is the one where the pKa is closest to the desired pH. It is possible to estimate the pKa for an acid (without a calculator) by taking the negative of the exponent for the different Ka values. This gives 1 for HIO3, 2 for HIO4, 4 for HNO2, and 10 for HCN. The HNO2 has the value closest to the desired pH. It would not be a good choice since the pKa is so far from the pH; however, it is the best choice.

content: At constant temperature, a change in the volume of the system will NOT affect the moles of the substances present in which of the following?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-As long as there are equal numbers of moles of gas on each side of the equilibrium arrow, then volume or pressure changes will not affect the equilibrium. The presence of solids, liquids, or aqueous phases does not make any difference as long as some of the phase is present.

content:
pH versus volume of titrant added
Ascorbic acid (vitamin C), H2C6O6, is a diprotic acid used as a dietary supplement. As with all dietary supplements, it is important to analyze samples for purity. The vitamin C may be extracted from natural sources or synthesized. The extraction vitamin C may contain additional extracted ingredients to which some people are allergic. Synthetic vitamin C may contain other forms of the vitamin; however, modern synthetic methods do not generate this contaminate. The above titration curve is an idealized graph for a diprotic acid. On this graph, E and F represent the pH at the endpoints with the possibility that E may shift slightly and one or the other may not be present. H is the volume of base required to titrate the first hydrogen ion and G is the quantity of base necessary to titrate both hydrogen ions. G is twice H.

What is the approximate pH at ½ H?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-The position ½ H is halfway to the first equivalence point. The pH at the halfway point is equal to pKa. The value of Ka1 is 8.0 × 10-5, which gives an approximate pKa of 5 (actual 4.1).

content:
pH versus volume of titrant added
Ascorbic acid (vitamin C), H2C6O6, is a diprotic acid used as a dietary supplement. As with all dietary supplements, it is important to analyze samples for purity. The vitamin C may be extracted from natural sources or synthesized. The extraction vitamin C may contain additional extracted ingredients to which some people are allergic. Synthetic vitamin C may contain other forms of the vitamin; however, modern synthetic methods do not generate this contaminate. The above titration curve is an idealized graph for a diprotic acid. On this graph, E and F represent the pH at the endpoints with the possibility that E may shift slightly and one or the other may not be present. H is the volume of base required to titrate the first hydrogen ion and G is the quantity of base necessary to titrate both hydrogen ions. G is twice H.

If G were not twice H, what would this indicate?

answers.A: <label>A. There is a contaminant that is either an acid or a base.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The other form of vitamin C is present.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The vitamin C was extracted from a plant.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-To reach H, it is necessary to convert all the ascorbic acid to the hydrogen ascorbate ion, which means the moles of hydrogen ascorbate ion formed must equal the moles of ascorbic acid originally present. The moles of hydrogen ascorbate ion formed would require the same number of moles of base as that required to convert the ascorbic acid to hydrogen ascorbate. Equal moles would mean equal volumes added.

Which of the following bases would be the best choice for the titration?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-In any acid-base titration, it is always easier to use a strong base (and a strong acid). Potassium hydroxide, KOH, is the only strong base among the choices.

In the titration of a sample of vitamin C, what is the approximate value of F?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-The titration of a weak acid with a strong base always has an equivalence point above 7.

content:
pH versus volume of titrant added
Ascorbic acid (vitamin C), H2C6O6, is a diprotic acid used as a dietary supplement. As with all dietary supplements, it is important to analyze samples for purity. The vitamin C may be extracted from natural sources or synthesized. The extraction vitamin C may contain additional extracted ingredients to which some people are allergic. Synthetic vitamin C may contain other forms of the vitamin; however, modern synthetic methods do not generate this contaminate. The above titration curve is an idealized graph for a diprotic acid. On this graph, E and F represent the pH at the endpoints with the possibility that E may shift slightly and one or the other may not be present. H is the volume of base required to titrate the first hydrogen ion and G is the quantity of base necessary to titrate both hydrogen ions. G is twice H.

While the titration of a diprotic acid to produce a curve similar to the idealized one above is useful in many analyses, ascorbic acid is not a good candidate for this type of analysis. Why?

answers.B: <label>B. Ascorbic acid may occur in more than one form.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Ascorbic acid is not soluble in water.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-Since Ka2 is Ka2 = 1.6 × 10-12, the pH at the equivalence point would be greater than 12, which is too high for a simple titration.

content: Which of the following CANNOT behave as both a Brønsted base and a Brønsted acid?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-All can behave as Brønsted bases (accept a hydrogen ion). Only B cannot behave as an acid (donate a hydrogen ion).

content: A student mixes 50.0 mL of 0.10 M potassium chromate, K2CrO4, solution with 50.0 mL of 0.10 M AgNO3. A red precipitate of silver chromate forms and the concentration of the silver ion becomes very small. Which of the following correctly places the concentrations of the remaining ions in order of decreasing concentration?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Initially, doubling the volume will result in halving the concentrations. Next, consider the reaction. The balanced equation is: K2CrO4(aq) + 2 AgNO3(aq) → Ag2CrO4(s) + 2 KNO3(aq). The silver ion is the limiting reagent, so very little remains in solution (due to its Ksp). The precipitation of silver chromate reduces the chromate concentration from 0.050 M. The nitrate does not change (soluble) remaining 0.050 M. Since two potassium ions (soluble) are formed per potassium chromate, after mixing the potassium ion concentration was 0.10 M and does not change (soluble).

content: There are a number of experiments for the determination of the molecular mass of a gas. One method begins by heating a solid or liquid in a flask to produce a gaseous product. The gas passes through a tube and displaces water in an inverted, water-filled bottle. The mass of the starting material is measured, along with the volume of the displaced water and the temperature of the system. The pressure in the inverted water-filled bottle is equal to the external pressure. Once the barometric pressure has been recorded, what other information is needed to finish the experiment?

answers.A: <label>A. The heat of formation of the gas</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The mass of the displaced water</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The vapor pressure of the water</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-To determine the molar mass of the gas it is necessary to know the mass of the gas (measured) and the moles of the gas. The ideal gas equation is necessary to determine the number of moles of gas present. To use the equation, it is necessary to know the temperature (measured), volume (measured = volume of displaced water), and pressure of the gas. The pressure of the gas is equal to the barometric pressure minus the vapor pressure of water. Water, whenever present, will contribute its vapor pressure.

content:
Using the information given above, calculate the enthalpy change for the following reaction:

2 C(s) + H2(g) → C2H2(g)
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A

content: Cerium(III) sulfate, Ce2(SO4)2, is less soluble in hot water than it is in cold. Which of the following conclusions may be related to this?

answers.A: <label>A. The heat of solution of cerium(III) sulfate is exothermic.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The hydration energies of cerium ions and sulfate ions are very low.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The heat of solution for cerium(III) sulfate is endothermic.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The solution is not an ideal solution.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-Since the compound is less soluble in hot water, the solution process must be exothermic. Exothermic processes shift toward the starting materials (solid cerium(III) sulfate) when heated.

content:
Use the information on the containers in the following diagram to answer questions.
Approximate molar masses:
He = 4 g mol-1, CH4 = 16 g mol-1,
O2 = 32 g mol-1, SO2 = 64 g mol-1

Under the conditions indicated, in which of the gas sample is the average velocity of the molecules half that of methane, CH4?

answers.D: <label>D. They are all at the same temperature; therefore, they have the same average velocity.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-The gases are all at the same temperature; therefore their average kinetic energies are the same. Since kinetic energy is equal to ½ mv2, ½ m1v12 = ½ m2v22, the subscripts refer to two different gases. Setting m1 = 16 g mol-1 and v2 = ½ v1 gives: ½ 16v12 = ½ m2(½ v1)2, this leads to: 16v12 = m2(1/4 v12). Rearranging and cancelling v1 yields m2 = 4(16) = 64 g mol-1.

content:
Use the information on the containers in the following diagram to answer questions.
Approximate molar masses:
He = 4 g mol-1, CH4 = 16 g mol-1,
O2 = 32 g mol-1, SO2 = 64 g mol-1

Which of the four gases will probably show the least deviation from ideal behavior?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-The smaller the molecule and the less polar (more nonpolar) the gas is, the smaller the deviation from ideal gas behavior.

content:
Use the information on the containers in the following diagram to answer questions.
Approximate molar masses:
He = 4 g mol-1, CH4 = 16 g mol-1,
O2 = 32 g mol-1, SO2 = 64 g mol-1

If one of the containers sprang a small leak, which of the following would change?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-Escaping gas would decrease the number of moles. Less gas remaining in the container would mean less pressure. The faster moving gas molecules would escape faster, lower the average velocity of those remaining in the container. A lower average velocity means a lower temperature.

content: The specific rate constant, k, for a certain first-order reaction is 86 h-1. What mass of a 0.0500 g sample of starting material will remain after 58 s?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-It is necessary to use the half-life relationship for first-order kinetics. This relationship is t1/2 = 0.693/k, and t1/2 = (0.693/86 h-1)(3600 s/h) = 29 s. To save time on the exam you can approximate this equation as t1/2 = (0.7/90)(3600). Dividing 3600 by 90 gives 40, and 40 times 0.7 is equal to 28. If the half-life is ≈ 28 s, then the time (58 s) is equivalent to about two half-lives, so one-fourth of the sample should remain.

content:
Use the information on the containers in the following diagram to answer questions concerning the following equilibrium:
CO(g) + 2 H2(g)  CH3OH(g)

Container A initially contains 0.60 mole of H2 and 0.60 mole of CO and is allowed to come to equilibrium. At equilibrium, there are 0.40 mole of CO in the flask. What is the value of Kc, the equilibrium constant, for the reaction?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-The loss of 0.20 mol of CO means that 0.40 mol of H2 reacted (leaving 0.20 mol) and 0.20 mol of CH3OH formed. Dividing all the moles by the volume gives the molarity, and:

Kc = (0.20)/(0.40)(0.20)2 = (0.10)/(0.20)(0.20)2 = 0.10/(0.20 × 0.04) = 0.10/0.008 = 12

content:
Use the information on the containers in the following diagram to answer questions concerning the following equilibrium:
CO(g) + 2 H2(g)  CH3OH(g)

A 1.00-mole sample of CH3OH is placed in container B and the system is allowed to go to equilibrium. What can be said about the relative rates of reaction with respect to the various components?

answers.A: <label>A. The rate of CO formation is numerically equal to the rate of CH<sub>3</sub>OH loss.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The rate of H<sub>2</sub> formation is numerically equal to the rate of CH<sub>3</sub>OH loss.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The rate of H<sub>2</sub>(g) formation is half the rate of CO(g) formation.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The rate of H<sub>2</sub>(g) formation is equal to the rate of CO(g) formation.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-Based upon the stoichiometry of the reaction, H2(g) will form twice as fast as CH3OH(g) disappears. The numerical values are the same; however, the rates have opposite signs.

content:
Use the information on the containers in the following diagram to answer questions concerning the following equilibrium:
CO(g) + 2 H2(g)  CH3OH(g)

The mixture in container D is in equilibrium. Which of the following is true?

answers.A: <label>A. The rate of the forward and reverse reactions is equal to zero.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of the reverse reaction.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The pressure in the system is increasing.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The pressure in the system is decreasing.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-At equilibrium, there is no net change because the forward and reverse reactions are going at the same rate.

content:
Use the information on the containers in the following diagram to answer questions concerning the following equilibrium:
CO(g) + 2 H2(g)  CH3OH(g)

The mixture in container A goes to equilibrium. If the initial moles of H2(g) is twice the initial moles of CO(g), which of the following is true?

answers.A: <label>A. Both reactants are limiting; therefore, the reaction will continue until there are zero moles of each remaining.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The total pressure of the system decreases until the system reaches equilibrium.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The total pressure of the system increases until the system equals equilibrium.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. No reaction occurs until a catalyst is added.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-As the reaction approaches equilibrium, there is a net decrease in the number of moles of gas present. A decrease in the number of moles of gas will lead to a decrease in pressure

content:
Use the information on the containers in the following diagram to answer questions concerning the following equilibrium:
CO(g) + 2 H2(g)  CH3OH(g)

As the mixture in container B approaches equilibrium, the partial pressure of CH3OH gas decreases by 1.5 atm. What is the net change in the total pressure of the system?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-The loss of 1.5 atm of CH3OH(g), based on stoichiometry leads to the formation of 1.5 atm of CO(g) and 3.0 atm of H2(g); therefore, the net change is (-1.5 + 1.5 + 3.0) atm = 3.0 atm.

content:
Use the information on standard reduction potentials in the following table to answer questions.

A student constructs an electrolysis cell with two inert electrodes in an aqueous solution that is 1.0 M in rubidium nitrite, RbNO2, and 1.0 M in rubidium hydroxide, RbOH. As the cell operates, an odorless gas evolves from one electrode and a gas with a distinctive odor evolves from the other electrode. Choose the correct statement from the following list.

answers.B: <label>B. The odorless gas is the result of reduction.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The gas with the distinctive odor is the result of oxidation.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The odorless gas evolves at the negative electrode.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-Oxygen (odorless) evolves at the anode (positive) and ammonia (distinctive odor) evolves at the cathode (negative). From the choices given, the only gas with a distinctive odor that could form is ammonia, NH3. For this reason, the nitrite ion half reaction must be the cathode reaction. The anode half reaction must be the reverse of one of the reactions in the table. The only one of the half reactions given that generates an odorless gas is the one involving oxygen, O2.

content:
Use the information on standard reduction potentials in the following table to answer questions.

There is a galvanic cell involving a lead, Pb, electrode in a 1.0 M lead(II) nitrate, Pb(NO3)2, solution and a chromium, Cr, electrode in a 1.0 M chromium(II) sulfate, CrSO4, solution. What is the cell potential?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-The lead electrode is the cathode (-0.13 V), and the chromium electrode is the anode (reverse sign, +0.91 V). Cell voltage = (-0.13 + 0.91) V = +0.78 V. The standard voltage of a galvanic cell is always positive.

content:
Use the information on standard reduction potentials in the following table to answer questions.

A student attempted to prepare an electrolysis cell to produce aluminum metal (Al) from an aqueous solution of aluminum chloride, AlCl3, using a 6.0 V battery. The cathode compartment of the electrolysis contained 1.0 M aluminum chloride. The student was unsuccessful. Why was the student unable to produce aluminum metal?

answers.A: <label>A. The voltage from the battery was insufficient to force the reaction to occur.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Reduction of chloride ion occurred in preference to reduction of calcium ion.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Calcium chloride solutions do not conduct electricity.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Reduction of water occurred in preference to reduction of calcium ion.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-It is necessary to consider all possible half reactions that might occur during electrolysis. Of the half reactions listed, only the reduction of water and the reduction of aluminum ions are applicable to this experiment. For any electrolysis, the half reaction requiring the least amount of energy will take place. So, while it is possible to reduce both water and the aluminum ion, the reduction potential for water is lower (requiring less energy), so water will reduce in preference to aluminum ion.

content:
Use the information on standard reduction potentials in the following table to answer questions.

Which of the substances in the table would be capable of reducing the aluminum ions in solid aluminum fluoride, AlF3, to aluminum metal? Assume the cell potentials in the table also apply to the solid state.
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-In order for substance A to reduce substance B, substance A must be a stronger reducing agent than substance B. Aluminum is a strong reducing agent as indicated by the large negative potential in the table (-1.66 V). The only substance in the table that has a more negative potential is rubidium, Rb (-2.93 V).

content:
Use the information on standard reduction potentials in the following table to answer questions.

A student constructs a galvanic cell that has a chromium, Cr, electrode in a compartment containing a 1.0 M chromium(II) nitrate, Cr(NO3)2, solution and a silver, Ag, electrode in a compartment containing 1.0 M silver nitrate, AgNO3, solution. A salt bridge containing a 1.0 M potassium chloride, KCl, solution connects the two compartments. When the student measures the cell potential, the value is far from the ideal predicted value. What is the cause of this discrepancy?

answers.C: <label>C. The potassium chloride in the salt bridge interfered with the reaction.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The student did not allow the cell to come to equilibrium.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Silver appears twice in the list of half reactions, once in the simple reduction of silver ions and once in the reduction of silver chloride, AgCl. The AgCl half reaction clearly shows that this compound is a solid. This solid will form as the silver ion in the silver nitrate solution reacts with chloride ion from the potassium chloride in the salt bridge. The formation of solid silver chloride will alter the concentration of the silver ion, which leads to a change in the cell potential.

content:
Use the information on the acids in the following diagram to answer questions.

Sample solutions of each of the three acids were titrated with 0.10 M sodium hydroxide, NaOH. Each of the acid solutions had a concentration of 0.10 M. Which of the acid titrations had the highest pH at the endpoint?

answers.D: <label>D. They all had a pH of 7 at the endpoint.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-The weakest acid (smallest Ka) will have the highest pH at the endpoint.

content:
Use the information on the acids in the following diagram to answer questions.

A student prepares three buffer solutions. Each solution is 1.0 M in one of the acids in the table and 1.0 M in its corresponding sodium salt. Which of the solutions has the greatest buffer capacity with respect to added NaOH and why?

answers.A: <label>A. The benzoic acid buffer because it is the strongest acid.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The chloroacetic acid buffer because it is the strongest acid.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The formic acid buffer because it donate both of its hydrogen atoms.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-The buffer capacity only depends on the number of moles present. All three solutions have the same number of moles.

content: Hypochlorous acid is an unstable compound, and one of the decomposition products is chlorine gas, Cl2. The decomposition of the acid lowers its concentration over time. What effect will the decomposition of one-fourth of the acid have on the agreement between the endpoint of the titration and the equivalence point during a titration with standard sodium hydroxide?

answers.A: <label>A. The endpoint would still remain near the ideal equivalence point.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The endpoint would be after the ideal equivalence point.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The endpoint would be before the ideal equivalence point.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-Less acid would require less than the ideal amount of base to reach the endpoint. Therefore, the endpoint would occur too soon.

content: Three 25.00 mL samples of approximately 0.10 M phenol, C6H5OH, Ka = 1.0 × 10-10 were removed from a container and placed in separate 250 mL beakers. The samples were titrated with standard potassium hydroxide, KOH, solution. Cresol red was the acid-base indicator used in the titration. The samples required 31.75, 32.38, and 41.75 mL to reach the endpoint. Which of the following might explain why one of the samples required significantly more base to reach the endpoint?

answers.A: <label>A. The indicator was added too late.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. There was a base contaminating the unclean beaker.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. There was an acid contaminating the unclean beaker.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-An acid contaminant was present and it would be necessary to add additional base to titrate this acid in addition to the phenol.

content: During the study of the reaction A → 2B, a chemist constructs several graphs. The graph of [A] versus time and the graph of ln [A] versus time both give a curved line; however, the graph of 1/[A] versus time and gives a straight line. This implies the rate law is
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B-Since only the plot of 1/[A] versus time yielded a straight line, this implies that the reaction is second-order in A.

content: The photoelectron spectrum of carbon has three equally sized peaks. What peak is at the lowest energy?

answers.A: <label>A. The 1s peak has the lowest energy.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The 2s peak has the lowest energy.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The 2p peak has the lowest energy.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The 1p peak has the lowest energy.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-The electron configuration of carbon in 1s22s2sp2. The removal of the last electron (2p) requires the least amount of energy.

content: According to the data in the table above, which of the compounds has the strongest intermolecular forces?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A-The compound with the highest boiling point has the strongest intermolecular forces. This is only valid if the molar masses are similar.

content: Each of the ions in the table form stable oxides (Na2O, CdO, and La2O3). Lanthanum oxide, La2O3, has a melting point significantly higher than that of the other oxides. Which of the following is the best explanation of why this is true?

answers.A: <label>A. Lanthanum is a lanthanide element and the melting points of these elements are always high.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. There is more oxygen in the formula La<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> than in the other formulas.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Lanthanum had the highest charge; therefore, it has the highest lattice energy.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Alkali metals like sodium and transition metals like cadmium tend to have low melting points.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C-The melting points of ionic materials depend upon the lattice energy. The higher the lattice energy, the higher the melting point is. Lattice energies depend upon the sizes of the ions and the magnitude of the charge. All three metal ions are approximately the same size; therefore, the size factor is minimal. This leaves the magnitude of the charge, and lanthanum, with the largest charge, should have the highest lattice energy.

content: Which of the following is the strongest Brønsted-Lowry acid?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D-Perbromic acid, HBrO4, is expected to be the strongest acid in this group because the greater number of oxygen atoms pulls more electron density from the hydrogen atom making it easier to be lost as a hydrogen ion.
